Cross references. —

For provision declaring water to be state property, see art. 8, § 1, Wyo. Const.

As to taxation and revenue generally, see art. 15, §§ 1 to 19, Wyo. Const.

As to eminent domain generally, see §§ 1-26-501 to 1-26-817 and Rule 71.1, W.R.C.P.

As to partition of real estate, see §§ 1-32-101 to 1-32-122.

For provision that failure of creditors to apply for letters testamentary, etc., shall not affect the lien upon encumbered property secured by valid mortgage or deed of trust in case of real property, or by security agreement under the UCC, see § 2-4-212.

As to sale of real and personal property by conservator, see §§ 3-3-607.

As to offenses against property generally, see §§ 6-3-101 to 6-3-901.

As to gifts, escheats and forfeitures to state generally, see §§ 9-5-201 to 9-5-205.

As to ownership of airspace and intrusions therein, see §§ 10-4-301 to 10-4-304.

As to sale of personal property and real estate in connection with insolvency and liquidation of banks, see § 13-4-401.

As to municipal zoning generally, see §§ 15-1-601 to 15-1-611.

As to assessments against property in connection with local improvements in cities and towns, see § 15-6-401 et seq.

For duties of county clerk with respect to records, see § 18-3-402.

As to mechanics and other similar liens generally, see title 29.

As to licensing of real estate brokers and of salesmen, see §§ 33-28-101 to 33-28-124.

As to property subject to taxation, see § 39-11-103 et seq.

As to listing real property for taxation annually, see § 39-13-103.

As to assessment of all property at fair value, see § 39-13-103.

As to sale of state lands generally, see §§ 36-9-101 to 36-9-120.

As to authority of railroads to sell, lease, etc., to other railroads outside of state, etc., see § 37-9-106.

As to payment of taxes as between grantor and grantee, see § 39-13-103.

Article 1. In General

  • § 34-1-101.  “Purchaser” defined.
  • § 34-1-102.  “Conveyance” defined.
  • § 34-1-103.  Letters of attorney; not a conveyance.
  • § 34-1-104.  Letters of attorney; recordation; effect as evidence.
  • § 34-1-105.  Letters of attorney; recordation; when revocation valid.
  • § 34-1-106.  Form and capacity of conveyances.
  • § 34-1-107.  Quitclaim deed.
  • § 34-1-108.  Married women; right to convey generally.
  • § 34-1-109.  Married women; right to convey all interest in land divested from husband; effect of conveyance.
  • § 34-1-110.  Married women; conveyance by nonresident.
  • § 34-1-111.  Conveyance by tenant for life.
  • § 34-1-112.  Claim of adverse possession not to invalidate conveyance.
  • § 34-1-113.  Acknowledgment of conveyances; generally.
  • §§ 34-1-114 through 34-1-117.  [Repealed.]
  • § 34-1-118.  Where conveyance to be recorded.
  • § 34-1-119.  Duties of county clerk generally.
  • § 34-1-120.  Unrecorded conveyance void as to subsequent purchasers recording first.
  • § 34-1-121.  Recorded instrument as notice to subsequent purchasers; recordation of instruments issued by United States or state of Wyoming.
  • § 34-1-122.  Force and effect of conveyances prior to act.
  • § 34-1-123.  Admissibility of conveyance or record thereof as evidence.
  • § 34-1-124.  Federal land office instruments; generally; railway maps and affidavits; recording and recording fees.
  • § 34-1-125.  Federal land office instruments; as evidence.
  • § 34-1-126.  [Repealed.]
  • § 34-1-127.  Effect on purported absolute conveyance of unrecorded deed of defeasance.
  • § 34-1-128.  Recorded assignment of mortgage.
  • § 34-1-129.  Husband or wife may appoint each other as attorney-in-fact to control interests.
  • § 34-1-130.  County clerk to discharge mortgage or deed of trust on record when certificate of release recorded.
  • § 34-1-131.  Force and effect of section 34-1-130 on mortgages and deeds of trust executed and deeds of trust discharged prior to act.
  • § 34-1-132.  Liability of mortgagee for failing to discharge; damage limitations; definition.
  • § 34-1-133.  Release; mortgage of deceased nonresident mortgagee.
  • § 34-1-134.  Release; mortgage of bankrupt corporation mortgagee.
  • § 34-1-135.  Covenants; not implied in conveyances; exception.
  • § 34-1-136.  Covenants; not implied for payment of sum secured by mortgage.
  • § 34-1-137.  Fees tail prohibited; future interests of fees tail; worthier title doctrine abolished.
  • § 34-1-138.  Perpetuities; short title.
  • § 34-1-139.  Perpetuities; time limits for vesting; restrictions on selected lives; legislative intent.
  • § 34-1-140.  Establishing joint tenancy or tenancy by entirety in real or personal property.
  • § 34-1-141.  Easements.
  • § 34-1-142.  Instrument transferring title to real property; procedure; exceptions; confidentiality.
  • § 34-1-143.  Information to be furnished to department of revenue and the state board of equalization.
  • § 34-1-144.  Penalty for falsifying statement.
  • § 34-1-145.  Definitions.
  • § 34-1-146.  Reconveyance of trust deed or release of mortgage; procedures; forms.
  • § 34-1-147.  Objections to reconveyance or release.
  • § 34-1-148.  Liability of title insurer or title agent.
  • § 34-1-149.  Application of provisions.
  • § 34-1-150.  Other sections not affected.
  • § 34-1-151.  Property disclosure statement.
  • § 34-1-152.  Ownership of pore space underlying surfaces.
  • § 34-1-153.  Ownership of material injected into geologic sequestration sites; liability for holding interests related to a sequestration site or giving consent to allow geologic sequestration activities.
  • § 34-1-154.  Removal of restrictive covenants in violation of law.
  • § 34-1-155.  Process for removing restrictive covenants in violation of law.
  • § 34-1-156.  Civil action for removing enforceable covenants.
  • § 34-1-157.  Ownership of fossils and artifacts.

Editor's notes. —

The article 1 designation and title have been added at the direction of the Wyoming legislative service office.

§ 34-1-101. “Purchaser” defined.

The term “purchaser”, as used in this act shall be construed to embrace every person to whom any estate or interest in real estate shall be conveyed for a valuable consideration, and also every assignee of a mortgage or lease, or other conditional estate.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 20; R.S. 1887, § 23; R.S. 1899, § 2729; C.S. 1910, § 3621; C.S. 1920, § 4577; R.S. 1931, § 97-102; C.S. 1945, § 66-123; W.S. 1957, § 34-1.

Cross references. —

As to recordation of probate judgments and decrees relating to real estate, see § 2-2-301.

Meaning of “this act.” —

The words “this act,” appearing in this section, refer to ch. 1, Laws 1882, which appears herein as this section and §§ 34-1-102 to 34-1-108, 34-1-110 to 34-1-113, 34-1-115, 34-1-116, 34-1-118 to 34-1-123, 34-1-126 to 34-1-128, 34-1-130, 34-1-132, 34-1-135 and 34-1-136.

Mortgagees are considered “purchasers” entitled to bona fide purchaser protection. Moreover, a lender who takes a mortgage on land has given value despite the fact that the “value” advanced is expected to be repaid. First Interstate Bank v. First Wyo. Bank, N.A., 762 P.2d 379, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 134 (Wyo. 1988).

Mortgagees are considered “purchasers” for purposes of the recording statute. —

District court properly granted summary judgment to a bank under Wyo. R. Civ. P. 56 in a mortgage foreclosure action because it would have been improper to apply the doctrine of equitable subrogation to allow a refinancing mortgagee to be subrogated to the priority lien position held by an original mortgagee as W.S. § 34-1-121 was clearly a filing date priority statute and the refinancing mortgagee, which was considered a purchaser under this statute, had constructive notice of a prior lien held by a bank. Countrywide Home Loans, Inc. v. First Nat'l Bank of Steamboat Springs, 2006 WY 132, 144 P.3d 1224, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 146 (2006).

Assignees were purchasers, but not bona fide purchasers. —

Trial court properly dismissed assignees' action against defendants for a declaration that an easement was void; the assignees, who were “purchasers” within the meaning of the recording act, could not demonstrate that they were bona fide purchasers, where the assignment itself reflected a defect in the title, i.e., it was retained by the State of Wyoming. Any effort to check the records would have revealed that the assignor lacked the ability to convey legal title. Bentley v. Dir. of the Office of State Lands & Invs., 2007 WY 94, 160 P.3d 1109, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 102 (Wyo. 2007).

Pleading good faith purchase. —

If it is necessary to plead purchase in good faith in action to quiet title by grantee in subsequently executed but first recorded deed from same grantor, it is plaintiff-grantee's duty to do it. York v. James, 60 Wyo. 222, 148 P.2d 596, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1944).

Burden of proving good faith purchase on subsequent grantee. —

Burden to prove that he was purchaser in good faith for valuable consideration and without notice is upon grantee under subsequent conveyance which is first recorded in quiet title action. York v. James, 60 Wyo. 222, 148 P.2d 596, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1944).

Issue of consideration raised. —

In quiet title action by grantee in subsequently executed but first recorded deed from same grantor, where plaintiff did not plead source of title and defendant denied plaintiff's title, question of consideration for subsequent deed was put in issue as near as possible in view of pleadings. York v. James, 60 Wyo. 222, 148 P.2d 596, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1944).

Effect of recital of consideration. —

Recitals of consideration in subsequently executed but first recorded deed from same grantor are not evidence of consideration against first grantee, except where parties to subsequent conveyance are dead. York v. James, 60 Wyo. 222, 148 P.2d 596, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1944).

Inadequate consideration. —

Payment by attorney to client of nine dollars and some cents for taxes client had paid during year and absorbing $15.00 charge to client for writing 3 or 4 letters concerning grazing lease and for taking notary to client was not fair or adequate consideration for deed to 320 acres of homestead realty. York v. James, 62 Wyo. 184, 165 P.2d 109, 1946 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1946).

Insufficient notice of prior conveyance. —

Provision in recorded lease of land for drilling water wells that lease payments should be made to lessors personally or in care of witness to instrument or deposited to lessors' credit in such witness' account was not enough to put subsequent purchaser on notice of previous unrecorded conveyance to such witness. York v. James, 62 Wyo. 184, 165 P.2d 109, 1946 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1946).

Defective assignment of palpable error noticed. —

Assignment of palpable error though defective in form will be noticed by supreme court where cursory examination of record shows judgment is not sustained by any evidence and is contrary to law. York v. James, 60 Wyo. 222, 148 P.2d 596, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1944).

Law reviews. —

See “Quitclaim Holder as a Bona Fide Purchaser,” 6 Wyo. L.J. 306.

§ 34-1-102. “Conveyance” defined.

The term “conveyance”, as used in this act, shall be construed to embrace every instrument in writing by which any estate or interest in real estate is created, alienated, mortgaged or assigned, or by which the title to any real estate may be affected in law or in equity, except wills, leases for a term not exceeding three (3) years, executory contracts for the sale or purchase of lands, and certificates which show that the purchaser has paid the consideration and is entitled to a deed for the lands, and contain a promise or agreement to furnish said deed at some future time.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 21; R.S. 1887, § 24; R.S. 1899, § 2728; C.S. 1910, § 3620; C.S. 1920, § 4576; R.S. 1931, § 97-101; C.S. 1945, § 66-124; W.S. 1957, § 34-2.

Meaning of “this act.” —

See note to § 34-1-101.

The transfer of title by eminent domain is not a conveyance within the meaning of this section. State ex rel. State Highway Comm'n v. Meeker, 75 Wyo. 210, 294 P.2d 603, 1956 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1956).

Purchasers were not bona fide. —

Trial court properly dismissed assignees' action against defendants for a declaration that an easement was void; the assignees, who were “purchasers” within the meaning of the recording act, could not demonstrate that they were bona fide purchasers, where the assignment itself reflected a defect in the title, i.e., it was retained by the State of Wyoming. Any effort to check the records would have revealed that the assignor lacked the ability to convey legal title. Bentley v. Dir. of the Office of State Lands & Invs., 2007 WY 94, 160 P.3d 1109, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 102 (Wyo. 2007).

Lease executed by agent. —

A lease for a term not exceeding 3 years, purported to be executed by an agent, was not rendered inadmissible in evidence against principal because no authority under seal was shown to have been given the agent. Marshall v. Rugg, 6 Wyo. 270, 44 P. 700, 1896 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1896).

Authorization to use right-of-way through lease. —

Court properly concluded that a lease and its concomitant authorization for an easement holder to use the right-of-way was efficacious where the easement holder already had a second right-of-way through acquisitions of rights-of-way held by its predecessors in interest, and the easement holder's use of another entity's right-of-way did not create a significant additional burden to that right-of-way or the interest a landowner had in it. In addition, the landowner cited no pertinent authority nor did he make a cogent argument that the circumstances amounted to a violation of the statute of frauds that invalidated the lease agreement between a television station and the easement holder. Cundy v. Range Tel. Coop., Inc., 2005 WY 153, 123 P.3d 901, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 2005).

Eviction by false representation. —

Under 5 year lease containing clause, that if any part of the real estate is sold, lease may be terminated at any yearly period on 90 days notice, falsely representing a sale and cancelling lease was not necessarily deceit, but plaintiff might maintain an action for breach of contract or tort on theory of eviction by false representations. Diamond Cattle Co. v. Clark, 52 Wyo. 265, 74 P.2d 857, 1937 Wyo. LEXIS 52 (Wyo. 1937).

Construction of recording laws. —

Recording laws should not be construed so as to produce fraud. Hawkins v. Stoffers, 40 Wyo. 226, 276 P. 452, 1929 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1929).

Attachment of acknowledged description to unacknowledged escrow agreement. —

An escrow agreement, although not recordable because unacknowledged, does not become recordable by purchaser's attachment to it of his acknowledged description and, when recorded, does not constitute constructive notice to subsequent purchasers of initial purchaser's interest. Low v. Sanger, 478 P.2d 60, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 214 (Wyo. 1970).

Failure to record executory contract for sale or purchase of land. —

It is true that an executory contract for the sale or purchase of land is not by statute required to be recorded, and therefore, failure to record such an instrument does not vitiate it as to subsequent purchasers — interests thus engendered being determined according to general principles of law and equity, which give weight to numerous common-law maxims, including the one that, “he who is first in time has the better right.” However, the mere chronology of transactions is not sufficient to bring such principles to play in favor of a defendant. Low v. Sanger, 478 P.2d 60, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 214 (Wyo. 1970).

Possession as notice of interest in land. —

Where purchaser in good faith was in possession when deed by vendor given to another company was placed of record, and purchaser was shown by evidence not to know anything of deed until thereafter, such possession held to give notice to world of interest in land, and such deed was absolutely void as to him. Hawkins v. Stoffers, 40 Wyo. 226, 276 P. 452, 1929 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1929).

Quoted in

Ayres Jewelry Co. v. O & S Bldg., 419 P.2d 628, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 173 (Wyo. 1966); Marple v. Wyoming Prod. Credit Ass'n, 750 P.2d 1315, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1988); Star Valley Ranch Ass'n v. Daley, 2014 WY 116, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 133 (Sept. 17, 2014).

Stated in

Laramie Printing Trustees v. Krueger, 437 P.2d 856, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 158 (Wyo. 1968).

Cited in

Wyoming Dep't of Revenue & Taxation-Excise Tax Div. v. First Wyo. Bank, 718 P.2d 31, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 540 (Wyo. 1986); Foster v. Wicklund, 778 P.2d 118, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 187 (Wyo. 1989); Horse Creek Conservation Dist. v. State Ex Rel. Wyo. Ag, 2009 WY 143, 221 P.3d 306, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 156 (Nov. 23, 2009).

Law reviews. —

See “Recording the Land Contract,” 6 Wyo. L.J. 208.

See “Quitclaim Holder as a Bona Fide Purchaser,” 6 Wyo. L.J. 306.

See “A Possible Bar to Implied Covenants in Wyoming Oil and Gas Leases,” 11 Wyo. L.J. 57.

For comment, “Landlord-Tenant Reform: Toward a Warranty of Habitability for Leased Residential Premises in Wyoming,” see XVIII Land & Water L. Rev. 765 (1983).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Deeds: description of land conveyed by reference to river or stream as carrying to thread or center or only to bank thereof — modern status, 78 ALR3d 604.

§ 34-1-103. Letters of attorney; not a conveyance.

The preceding section [§ 34-1-102] shall not be construed to extend to a letter of attorney, or other instrument, containing a power to convey lands as agent or attorney for the owner of such lands.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 22; R.S. 1887, § 25; R.S. 1899, § 2730; C.S. 1910, § 3622; C.S. 1920, § 4578; R.S. 1931, § 97-103; C.S. 1945, § 66-125; W.S. 1957, § 34-3.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Real estate broker's authority under power of attorney to execute contract for sale on behalf of principal, 43 ALR2d 1014.

§ 34-1-104. Letters of attorney; recordation; effect as evidence.

Every letter of attorney, or other instrument, containing a power to convey lands as agent or attorney for the owner of such lands, and every executory contract for the sale or purchase of lands, only when acknowledged by such owner, may be recorded by the county clerk of any county in which the lands to which such letter, instrument or contract relates, or any part of such lands, may be situated, and when so acknowledged, and the record thereof when recorded, or a transcript of such record duly certified, may be read in evidence in the same manner and with like effect as a conveyance recorded in such county.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 22; R.S. 1887, § 25; R.S. 1899, § 2755; C.S. 1910, § 3647; C.S. 1920, § 4603; Laws 1931, ch. 28, § 1; R.S. 1931, § 97-128; C.S. 1945, § 66-127; W.S. 1957, § 34-4; Laws 2009, ch. 168, § 206.

Cross references. —

As to introduction in evidence of instruments concerning real estate, see § 34-1-123.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, substituted “county clerk” for “register of deeds.”

A power of attorney is not required for an agent to accept a conveyance of mining claims, since this section only applies to a conveyance by an agent. North Am. Uranium v. Johnston, 77 Wyo. 332, 316 P.2d 325, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1957).

Alteration of unrecordable instrument to make it recordable. —

It would be strange indeed if the person to whom a transfer is made by an unacknowledged and thereby unrecordable instrument could unilaterally and to his own benefit alter such an instrument so as to make it recordable. The legislature did not intend the statutes to permit this result nor should such interpretation be countenanced in equity. Low v. Sanger, 478 P.2d 60, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 214 (Wyo. 1970).

Failure to record executory contract for sale or purchase of land. —

It is true that an executory contract for the sale or purchase of land is not by statute required to be recorded, and therefore, failure to record such an instrument does not vitiate it as to subsequent purchasers — interests thus engendered being determined according to general principles of law and equity, which give weight to numerous common-law maxims, including the one that, “he who is first in time has the better right.” However, the mere chronology of transactions is not sufficient to bring such principles to play in favor of a defendant. Low v. Sanger, 478 P.2d 60, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 214 (Wyo. 1970).

Attachment of acknowledged description to unacknowledged escrow agreement. —

An escrow agreement, although not recordable because unacknowledged, does not become recordable by purchaser's attachment to it of his acknowledged description and, when recorded, does not constitute constructive notice to subsequent purchasers of initial purchaser's interest. Low v. Sanger, 478 P.2d 60, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 214 (Wyo. 1970).

Law reviews. —

See “Recording the Land Contract,” 6 Wyo. L.J. 208.

§ 34-1-105. Letters of attorney; recordation; when revocation valid.

No letter of attorney, or other instrument so recorded, shall be deemed to be revoked by any act of the party by whom it was executed, unless the instrument containing such revocation be also recorded in the same office in which the instrument containing the power was recorded.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 23; R.S. 1887, § 26; R.S. 1899, § 2756; C.S. 1910, § 3648; C.S. 1920, § 4604; R.S. 1931, § 97-129; C.S. 1945, § 66-128; W.S. 1957, § 34-5.

Cited in

Boswell v. First Nat'l Bank, 16 Wyo. 161, 92 P. 624 (1907).

§ 34-1-106. Form and capacity of conveyances.

Conveyances of land or of any estate or interest therein, may be made by instrument executed and acknowledged by the party from whom or which the estate or interest is intended to pass.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 1; R.S. 1887, § 1; R.S. 1899, § 2731; C.S. 1910, § 3623; C.S. 1920, § 4579; R.S. 1931, § 97-104; Laws 1943, ch. 76, § 1; C.S. 1945, § 66-101; W.S. 1957, § 34-6.

Holders of construction permits. —

Where holders of permits to construct an irrigation ditch executed instruments purporting to “transfer, sell, release” and “transfer, sell, assign, and set over” all their right and title to appropriation, such instruments, though not acknowledged and recorded as required, were sufficient to pass title as between parties. Whalon v. North Platte Canal & Colonization Co., 11 Wyo. 313, 71 P. 995, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1903).

Cited in

Marshall v. Rugg, 6 Wyo. 270, 44 P. 700, 1896 Wyo. LEXIS 14, 33 L.R.A. 679 (1896); Ohio Oil Co. v. Wyoming Agency, 63 Wyo. 187, 179 P.2d 773, 1947 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (1947).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Effectiveness of reservation of vendor's crop rights in land contracts in absence of such reservation in deed later executed, 8 ALR2d 565.

§ 34-1-107. Quitclaim deed.

A deed of quitclaim and release shall be sufficient to pass all the estate which the grantor could lawfully convey by deed of bargain and sale.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 3; R.S. 1887, § 3; R.S. 1899, § 2733; C.S. 1910, § 3625; C.S. 1920, § 4581; R.S. 1931, § 97-106; C.S. 1945, § 66-103; W.S. 1957, § 34-7.

Cross references. —

As to form and effect generally of quitclaim deed, see §§ 34-2-104, 34-2-105.

As to effect of quitclaim deed without the word “release,” see § 34-2-106.

Disqualified witness. —

A deed is good between parties, notwithstanding disqualified witness. Huber v. Glenrock State Bank, 32 Wyo. 357, 231 P. 63, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 2 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 32 Wyo. 357, 234 P. 31, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1925).

Applied in

S & G Investors, LLC v. Blackley, 994 P.2d 941, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 2000).

Law reviews. —

For a note, “Quitclaim Holder as a Bona Fide Purchaser,” see 6 Wyo. L.J. 306.

§ 34-1-108. Married women; right to convey generally.

A married woman may, by her deed or mortgage, convey her real estate in like manner as she might, if she were an unmarried woman.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 2; R.S. 1887, § 2; R.S. 1899, § 2732; C.S. 1910, § 3624; C.S. 1920, § 4580; R.S. 1931, § 97-105; C.S. 1945, § 66-102; W.S. 1957, § 34-8.

Cross references. —

For provision that conveyance or encumbrance of homestead void unless wife joins, and as to exception thereto, see § 34-2-121.

As to power of married women to convey, etc., property and to contract, see § 20-1-202.

Cited in

Fox v. Fox, 75 Wyo. 390, 296 P.2d 252, 1956 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (1956).

§ 34-1-109. Married women; right to convey all interest in land divested from husband; effect of conveyance.

In all cases where the interest of the husband in any tract or parcel of land has been, or shall be, divested by process of law, or by voluntary conveyance or otherwise, the wife may, by her separate deed, release and convey to the purchaser, his heirs or grantees, all her interest in such tract or parcel of land, whether in possession or expectancy, in the same manner as though she were sole and unmarried; and any deed by the wife so executed and acknowledged, shall be a valid and sufficient bar in law and equity to any right or choice of dower, or other interest which she may thereafter assert in such premises.

History.

Laws 1888, ch. 75, § 1; R.S. 1899, § 4139; C.S. 1910, § 4999; C.S. 1920, § 6269; R.S. 1931, § 89-3933; C.S. 1945, § 3-7201; W.S. 1957, § 34-9.

Cross references. —

As to rights and liabilities of married person generally, see §§ 20-1-201, 20-1-202.

Editor's notes. —

As enacted, this section contained a first sentence which read: “A married woman may relinquish her dower in any of the real estate of her husband in a deed, mortgage, conveyance, power of attorney, release, or other disposition thereof.” The 1899 revisor and all subsequent revisors omitted such sentence.

Dower abolished. —

This and other sections were cited to the effect that dower has been abolished in this state. France v. Connor, 3 Wyo. 445, 27 P. 569, 1891 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1891), aff'd, 161 U.S. 65, 16 S. Ct. 497, 40 L. Ed. 619, 1896 U.S. LEXIS 2138 (U.S. 1896).

Cited in

Fox v. Fox, 75 Wyo. 390, 296 P.2d 252, 1956 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (1956).

§ 34-1-110. Married women; conveyance by nonresident.

When any married woman, not residing in this state, shall join her husband in any conveyance of real estate situated within this state, the conveyance shall have the same effect as if she were sole, and the acknowledgment of proof of the execution of such conveyance by her, may be the same as if she were sole.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 11; R.S. 1887, § 13; R.S. 1899, § 2747; C.S. 1910, § 3639; C.S. 1920, § 4595; R.S. 1931, § 97-120; C.S. 1945, § 66-113; W.S. 1957, § 34-10.

Cited in

State ex rel. Nash v. Cowhick, 9 Wyo. 93, 60 P. 265, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (1900); Fox v. Fox, 75 Wyo. 390, 296 P.2d 252, 1956 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (1956).

§ 34-1-111. Conveyance by tenant for life.

A conveyance made by a tenant for life or years, purporting to grant a greater estate than he possessed or could lawfully convey, shall not work a forfeiture of his estate, but shall pass to the grantee all the estate which such tenant could lawfully convey.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 4; R.S. 1887, § 4; R.S. 1899, § 2736; C.S. 1910, § 3628; C.S. 1920, § 4584; R.S. 1931, § 97-109; C.S. 1945, § 66-104; W.S. 1957, § 34-11.

§ 34-1-112. Claim of adverse possession not to invalidate conveyance.

No grant or conveyance of lands or interest therein shall be void, for the reason that at the time of the execution thereof, such land shall be in the actual possession of another, claiming adversely.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 7; R.S. 1887, § 7; R.S. 1899, § 2735; C.S. 1910, § 3627; C.S. 1920, § 4583; R.S. 1931, § 97-108; C.S. 1945, § 66-107; W.S. 1957, § 34-12.

Cross references. —

As to Marketable Title Act not affecting rights acquired by adverse possession, see § 34-10-104.

As to establishment of public highways generally, and as to creation by adverse possession, etc., see § 24-1-101.

Cited in

Freeman v. Crout, 1 Wyo. 360, 1 Wyo. 361, 1877 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (1877).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Public records as notice of adverse possession in life tenant as against remaindermen or reversioners, 58 ALR2d 299.

§ 34-1-113. Acknowledgment of conveyances; generally.

Execution of deeds, mortgages or other conveyances of lands, or any interest in lands, shall be acknowledged by the party or parties executing same, before any notarial officer. The notarial officer taking such acknowledgment shall comply with the requirements of W.S. 32-3-109.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 8; 1884, ch. 29, § 1; R.S. 1887, § 8; R.S. 1899, § 2741; Laws 1905, ch. 24, § 1; C.S. 1910, § 3633; C.S. 1920, § 4589; R.S. 1931, § 97-114; Laws 1941, ch. 79, § 1; 1943, ch. 76, § 2; C.S. 1945, § 66-108; W.S. 1957, § 34-13; Laws 1973, ch. 33, § 1; 2004, ch. 42, § 1; 2008, ch. 20, § 2; 2021, ch. 27, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to acknowledgment of townsites with reference to platting of subdivisions, etc., see § 34-12-103.

As to officers authorized to administer oaths, see § 1-2-102.

As to issuance of certificate by notary public without proper acknowledgment, see § 6-5-114.

As to notaries public, see title 32.

The 2004 amendment deleted “justice of the peace” following “or any county clerk.”

Laws 2004, ch. 42, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 3, 2004.

The 2008 amendment, effective July 1, 2008, rewrote the section.

The 2021 amendment, effective July 1, 2021, substituted "32-3-109" for "34-26-107" at the end of the second sentence.

Construction of former requirement that conveyance be witnessed. —

The requirement of R.S. 1931, § 97-114, that a conveyance of land should be executed in the presence of 1 witness who should subscribe as such, while necessary for recordation of the instrument, did not affect its validity as between the parties. Ohio Oil Co. v. Wyoming Agency, 63 Wyo. 187, 179 P.2d 773, 1947 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1947).

Validity between parties. —

This section does not affect the validity of an unwitnessed mortgage as between the parties. Conradt v. Lepper, 13 Wyo. 473, 81 P. 307, 1905 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 13 Wyo. 473, 81 P. 307, 1905 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1905).

Separate statement of wife. —

The failure of a certificate to state expressly that the wife was examined “separate and apart from her husband” did not render it void. Adams v. Smith, 11 Wyo. 200, 70 P. 1043, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1903).

Sufficiency on face. —

Where an instrument is sufficient on its face, it is entitled to be recorded, and imparts constructive notice to an execution creditor. Smith v. Jackson State Bank, 63 F.2d 934, 1933 U.S. App. LEXIS 3638 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1933).

Requirements not satisfied. —

Summary judgment in favor of a homeowner in an association's action seeking to enforce an amendment to a subdivision's restrictive covenants was affirmed because since not all of the signatures approving the amendment satisfied the requirements of Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 34-1-113, not all of the signatures were valid and thus, the amendment did not attain the 75 percent approval requirement necessary to enact the amendment. Riverview Heights Homeowners' Ass'n v. Rislov, 2009 WY 55, 205 P.3d 1035, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 55 (Wyo. 2009).

Copies of Documents. —

When a title agency attempted to file a copy, with additional language, of an original document that had already been filed with the county clerk, the supreme court rejected the title agency's president's argument that the county clerk should have accepted the document for filing because, if the supreme court were to accept the argument, the door would be open to the filing of mere copies not eligible for recording. State Ex Rel. Bunn, 2005 WY 100, 117 P.3d 1253, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 120 (2005).

Documents properly notarized. —

See Bowers Welding & Hotshot, Inc. v. Bromley, 699 P.2d 299, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 480 (Wyo. 1985).

Quoted in

Star Valley Ranch Ass'n v. Daley, 2014 WY 116, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 133 (Sept. 17, 2014).

Applied in

Thomas v. Roth, 386 P.2d 926, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 122 (Wyo. 1963).

Cited in

Whalon v. North Platte Canal & Colonization Co., 11 Wyo. 313, 71 P. 995, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (1903); Boswell v. First Nat'l Bank, 16 Wyo. 161, 92 P. 624, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (1907).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Sufficiency of certificate of acknowledgment, 25 ALR2d 1124.

Effect of acknowledgment of instrument upon determination of its character as will or deed, 31 ALR2d 532.

Record of instrument without sufficient acknowledgment as notice, 59 ALR2d 1299.

Library References. —

American Law of Mining, 2nd Edition § 131.02 (Matthew Bender).

§§ 34-1-114 through 34-1-117. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2008, ch. 20, § 3.

Editor's notes. —

These sections, which derived from Laws 1890, ch. 61, § 2, Laws 1882, ch. 1, §§ 9 and 10, and Laws 1886, ch. 110, § 1, related to notification of expiration dates for conveyances and to conveyances executed outside the state.

§ 34-1-118. Where conveyance to be recorded.

A certificate of the acknowledgment of any deed, mortgage or conveyance, or proof of the execution thereof, before a notarial officer, shall entitle such deed, mortgage or conveyance, certificate or certificates aforesaid, to be recorded in the office of the county clerk in the county where the land lies.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 12; R.S. 1887, § 15; R.S. 1899, § 2754; C.S. 1910, § 3646; C.S. 1920, § 4602; R.S. 1931, § 97-127; C.S. 1945, § 66-114; W.S. 1957, § 34-18; Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 1; 2008, ch. 20, § 2.

Cross references. —

For provision requiring recordation of mortgage in connection with foreclosure and power of sale, see § 34-4-103.

The 2004 amendment substituted “county clerk” for “register of deeds.”

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 19, 2004.

The 2008 amendment, effective July 1, 2008, substituted “notarial officer” for “court of record or a justice of the peace, signed by the clerk of such court, (or by the justice) before whom the same was taken, as provided in this act, and in the cases where the same is necessary, the certificate required by W.S. 34-1-115.”

Editor's notes. —

Laws 2004, ch. 42, § 1, generally deleted references to “justice of the peace”; presumably, failure to do so here was an oversight.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

An affidavit is not a “deed, mortgage or conveyance” entitled to be recorded under this section. Thomas v. Roth, 386 P.2d 926, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 122 (Wyo. 1963).

Thus, affidavits are not eligible for recordation, even if they have been sufficiently acknowledged. Thomas v. Roth, 386 P.2d 926, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 122 (Wyo. 1963).

Recording ineligible instrument does not give constructive notice. —

The recording of an instrument, which is not a proper subject of recordation, does not operate to give constructive notice of the contents of the instrument to prospective purchasers or encumbrancers of the property. Thomas v. Roth, 386 P.2d 926, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 122 (Wyo. 1963).

Nor does recording unacknowledged instrument. —

If an instrument, required for recordation to be acknowledged, is without an acknowledgment and is admitted to record, the recordation does not afford constructive notice of the existence and contents of the instrument. Thomas v. Roth, 386 P.2d 926, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 122 (Wyo. 1963).

Stated in

Torgeson v. Connelly, 348 P.2d 63, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1959); Esterholdt v. Pacificorp, 2013 WY 64, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 68 (May 22, 2013).

Cited in

State ex rel. Nash v. Cowhick, 9 Wyo. 93, 60 P. 265, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (1900).

Law reviews. —

For an article, “Recording the Land Contract,” see 6 Wyo. L.J. 208.

For a note, “Wyoming Recording Statutes and the Bankruptcy Act,” see 7 Wyo. L.J. 109.

“A Possible Bar to Implied Covenants in Wyoming Oil and Gas Leases,” 11 Wyo. L.J. 57.

§ 34-1-119. Duties of county clerk generally.

  1. The county clerk of each county within this state shall receive and record at length all deeds, mortgages, conveyances, patents, certificates and instruments left with him for that purpose, and he shall endorse on every such instrument the day and hour on which it was filed for record. The county clerk shall not record any document until the address of the grantee, mortgagee or assignee of the mortgagee is furnished to the county clerk, but this requirement shall not affect the validity of the recording of any instrument except to the extent provided in W.S. 34-1-142(b). Only instruments which are the originally signed documents, including electronic documents recorded pursuant to the Uniform Real Property Electronic Recording Act, W.S. 34-1-401 through 34-1-407, or properly certified or authenticated copies thereof may be properly recorded. A document is properly certified if in compliance with Rule 902 of the Wyoming Rules of Evidence or other applicable rule or statute.
  2. Whenever a transfer on death deed is filed with the county clerk pursuant to W.S. 2-18-103, the county clerk shall furnish the following information to the Wyoming department of health, division of healthcare financing within fourteen (14) days of recording the deed:
    1. The name of the grantor;
    2. The name of the grantee;
    3. The legal description of the property being transferred.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 13; R.S. 1887, § 16; R.S. 1899, § 2760; C.S. 1910, § 3652; C.S. 1920, § 4608; R.S. 1931, § 97-133; C.S. 1945, § 66-115; W.S. 1957, § 34-19; Laws 1975, ch. 79, § 1; 1981, ch. 95, § 1; 2013, ch. 100, § 2; 2016, ch. 60, § 2; 2020, ch. 72, § 1.

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, added (b), designating the existing provisions as (a).

The 2016 amendment, effective January 1, 2017, inserted “including electronic documents recorded pursuant to the Uniform Real Property Electronic Recording Act, W.S. 34-1-401 through 34-1-407,” following “originally signed documents” in (a).

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in (a) added “except to the extent provided in W.S. 34-1-142(b)” at the end of the second sentence.

Copies of Documents. —

District court properly refused to issue a writ of mandamus to a county clerk; a document that a title agency sought to file with the county clerk was merely a copy, with additions, of an original document that had already been filed with the clerk. State Ex Rel. Bunn, 2005 WY 100, 117 P.3d 1253, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 120 (2005).

Quoted in

Esterholdt v. Pacificorp, 2013 WY 64, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 68 (May 22, 2013); Star Valley Ranch Ass'n v. Daley, 2014 WY 116, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 133 (Sept. 17, 2014).

§ 34-1-120. Unrecorded conveyance void as to subsequent purchasers recording first.

Every conveyance of real estate within this state, hereafter made, which shall not be recorded as required by law, shall be void, as against any subsequent purchaser or purchasers in good faith and for a valuable consideration of the same real estate or any portion thereof, whose conveyance shall be first duly recorded.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 15; R.S. 1887, § 18; R.S. 1899, § 2762; C.S. 1910, § 3654; C.S. 1920, § 4610; R.S. 1931, § 97-135; C.S. 1945, § 66-119; W.S. 1957, § 34-20.

Cross references. —

For provision requiring recordation of mortgage in connection with foreclosure and power of sale, see § 34-4-103.

The transfer of title by eminent domain is not a conveyance within the meaning of this section. State ex rel. State Highway Comm'n v. Meeker, 75 Wyo. 210, 294 P.2d 603, 1956 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1956).

And the failure to record an instrument which is not required to be recorded does not affect or vitiate the instrument as to anyone, and it is valid not only between the parties thereto, but also as to subsequent purchasers and encumbrances. State ex rel. State Highway Comm'n v. Meeker, 75 Wyo. 210, 294 P.2d 603, 1956 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1956).

Where the state acquired land by eminent domain under condemnation proceedings in 1950, the title the state acquired was valid and good against any subsequent purchaser, since prior to 1953 no statute required the transfer of title by eminent domain to be recorded in the ordinary and regular books of record kept for transfer of property by conveyances. State ex rel. State Highway Comm'n v. Meeker, 75 Wyo. 210, 294 P.2d 603, 1956 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1956).

Unacknowledged instrument is not entitled to be recorded. —

An instrument of conveyance which was not acknowledged was not entitled to be placed of record under the laws of this state. North Am. Uranium v. Johnston, 77 Wyo. 332, 316 P.2d 325, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1957); Torgeson v. Connelly, 348 P.2d 63, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1959) sub. nom.Markey v. Connelly, 367 P.2d 964, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 58 (Wyo. 1962).

Where there are conveyances of adjoining parcels in a tract of land, this section applies only to the parties to whom there was a conveyance “of the same real estate or any portion thereof …,” and where the conveyances to the other land owners conflicted with no others, they acquired good title against all the world without recording. Condos v. Trapp, 739 P.2d 749, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 467 (Wyo. 1987).

Judgment creditor not protected against prior unrecorded conveyance. —

Where trust deed, though not entitled to record for failure to comply with statute, is good as between the parties, a judgment creditor, before sale of mortgaged premises under execution issued on his judgment, is not subsequent purchaser in good faith for value protected against a prior unrecorded conveyance. Frank v. Hicks, 4 Wyo. 502, 35 P. 475, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 4 Wyo. 502, 35 P. 475, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1894).

No collateral attack on unrecorded deed executed before bankruptcy. —

There being no subsequent purchaser in good faith before the court, a deed conveying Wyoming land, executed more than 4 months before bankruptcy petition was filed, though not recorded, was not subject to attack as preferential under Bankruptcy Act. Hoshaw v. Cosgriff, 247 F. 22, 1917 U.S. App. LEXIS 1630 (8th Cir. Wyo. 1917).

Purchasers were not bona fide due to title defect. —

Trial court properly dismissed assignees' action against defendants for a declaration that an easement was void; the assignees, who were “purchasers” within the meaning of the recording act, could not demonstrate that they were bona fide purchasers, where the assignment itself reflected a defect in the title, i.e., it was retained by the State of Wyoming. Any effort to check the records would have revealed that the assignor lacked the ability to convey legal title. Bentley v. Dir. of the Office of State Lands & Invs., 2007 WY 94, 160 P.3d 1109, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 102 (Wyo. 2007).

Bona fide purchasers. —

Limited liability company (LLC) was not a bona fide purchaser of an irrigation district's property, but simply had an equity interest in the property. Because the contract for the sale of the property to the LLC was executory, there had been no conveyance of the property, and this section provided no remedy to the LLC. Horse Creek Conservation Dist. v. State Ex Rel. Wyo. Ag, 2009 WY 143, 221 P.3d 306, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 156 (Nov. 23, 2009).

Doctrine of bona fide purchaser applies even when deed's original grantor alleges incompetence. Such a deed is voidable, not void. As against voidable deeds, the protections granted under the doctrine of bona fide purchaser are complete and apply regardless of the state of the grantor's competence, so long as the purchaser had no notice of the claimed incompetence. First Interstate Bank v. First Wyo. Bank, N.A., 762 P.2d 379, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 134 (Wyo. 1988).

Pleading good faith purchase. —

If it is necessary to plead purchase in good faith in action to quiet title by grantee in subsequently executed but first recorded deed from same grantor, it is plaintiff's duty to do it. York v. James, 60 Wyo. 222, 148 P.2d 596, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1944).

Burden of proving good faith purchase on subsequent grantee. —

In the case of York v. James, 60 Wyo. 222, 148 P.2d 596, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (1944), the court held that the burden of proof is on the subsequent purchaser to show that he purchased the property in question in good faith and without notice. North Am. Uranium v. Johnston, 77 Wyo. 332, 316 P.2d 325, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1957).

Burden to prove that he was purchaser in good faith for valuable consideration and without notice is upon grantee under subsequent conveyance which is first recorded in quiet title action. York v. James, 60 Wyo. 222, 148 P.2d 596, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1944).

To avail themselves of this section and cut off the rights of a lessee, a purchaser from the lessor has the burden of proving he was a purchaser in good faith for valuable consideration and without notice. Soppe v. Breed, 504 P.2d 1077, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 131 (Wyo. 1973).

And was not sustained. —

Plaintiff, a subsequent purchaser of mining claims, did not sustain burden of proof that he purchased claims in good faith and without notice of prior conveyance of claims to defendant, where attorney testified that he told plaintiff that defendant had a prior conveyance of the claims, and that there would probably be a controversy as to the claims, since defendant claimed them as his own. North Am. Uranium v. Johnston, 77 Wyo. 332, 316 P.2d 325, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1957).

Failure to record an instrument does not render it void as to subsequent purchasers where prior to the conveyance the purchasers were put on due inquiry and where upon reasonable investigation the fact of the existence of the instrument could have been determined. Soppe v. Breed, 504 P.2d 1077, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 131 (Wyo. 1973).

Bad faith not established. —

Subsequent purchaser's actions did not constitute bad faith, removing her from the protection afforded by this section. Grose v. Sauvageau, 942 P.2d 398, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 100 (Wyo. 1997).

Issue of consideration raised. —

In quiet title action by grantee in subsequently executed but first recorded deed from same grantor, where plaintiff did not plead source of title and defendant denied plaintiff's title, question of consideration for subsequent deed was put in issue as near as possible in view of pleadings. York v. James, 60 Wyo. 222, 148 P.2d 596, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1944).

Effect of recital of consideration. —

Recitals of consideration in subsequently executed but first recorded deed from same grantor are not evidence of consideration against first grantee, except where parties to subsequent conveyance are dead. York v. James, 60 Wyo. 222, 148 P.2d 596, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1944).

Inadequate consideration. —

Payment by attorney to client of $9.00 and some cents for taxes client had paid during year and absorbing a $15.00 charge to client for writing 3 or 4 letters concerning grazing lease and for taking notary to client was not fair or adequate consideration for deed to 320 acres of homestead realty. York v. James, 62 Wyo. 184, 165 P.2d 109, 1946 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1946).

Insufficient notice of prior conveyance. —

Provision in recorded lease of land for drilling water wells that lease payments should be made to lessors personally or in care of witness to instrument or deposited to lessors' credit in such witness' account was not enough to put subsequent purchaser on notice of previous unrecorded conveyance to such witness. York v. James, 62 Wyo. 184, 165 P.2d 109, 1946 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1946).

Inquiry notice. —

Subsequent purchaser who diligently searched the records only to discover that occupants' possession of the property was consistent with the rights of the record owner was not put on inquiry notice. Grose v. Sauvageau, 942 P.2d 398, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 100 (Wyo. 1997).

Defective assignment of palpable error noticed. —

Assignment of palpable error though defective in form will be noticed by supreme court where cursory examination of record shows judgment is not sustained by any evidence and is contrary to law. York v. James, 60 Wyo. 222, 148 P.2d 596, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1944).

Applied in

Doenz v. Garber, 665 P.2d 932, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 339 (Wyo. 1983); Bowers Welding & Hotshot, Inc. v. Bromley, 699 P.2d 299, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 480 (Wyo. 1985).

Quoted in

Dame v. Mileski, 80 Wyo. 156, 340 P.2d 205, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 33 (1959); Wyoming Dep't of Revenue & Taxation-Excise Tax Div. v. First Wyo. Bank, 718 P.2d 31, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 540 (Wyo. 1986).

Cited in

Whalon v. North Platte Canal & Colonization Co., 11 Wyo. 313, 71 P. 995, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (1903); Hawkins v. Stoffers, 40 Wyo. 226, 276 P. 452, 1929 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (1929); Huber v. Delong, 54 Wyo. 240, 91 P.2d 53, 1939 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (1939).

Stated in

Esterholdt v. Pacificorp, 2013 WY 64, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 68 (May 22, 2013).

Law reviews. —

“Creditors' Rights Under the Recording Statutes,” 4 Wyo. L.J. 125.

“Recording the Land Contract,” 6 Wyo. L.J. 208.

“Quitclaim Holder as a Bona Fide Purchaser,” 6 Wyo. L.J. 306.

See comment, “Remedial Title Legislation for Wyoming,” VII Land & Water L. Rev. 561 (1972).

For article, “Wyoming Adopts the ‘1972 Amendments’ to Uniform Commercial Code Article 9 — The Revisions and Some Continuing Problems,” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 581 (1984).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Adverse possession by one claiming under or through deed by cotenant as affected by failure to record deed, 32 ALR2d 1214.

§ 34-1-121. Recorded instrument as notice to subsequent purchasers; recordation of instruments issued by United States or state of Wyoming.

  1. Each and every deed, mortgage, instrument or conveyance touching any interest in lands, made and recorded, according to the provisions of this chapter, shall be notice to and take precedence of any subsequent purchaser or purchasers from the time of the delivery of any instrument at the office of the county clerk, for record. Any and all instruments or other documents, or copies of instruments or other documents duly certified by any agency, department or bureau of the United States or the state of Wyoming having charge of the records of the instruments or other documents, conveying, remising or demising, or otherwise affecting:
    1. Real estate on any Indian reservation and relating to any period the real estate may be or has been held by the United States in trust for an Indian or Indians or Indian tribe, or restricted against alienation under the laws of the United States, or any interest in the real estate; or
    2. Real estate, or any interest therein, or any assignment thereof, issued by the United States or the state of Wyoming, or any agency, department or bureau of either thereof, including mineral leases and assignments thereof, certificates of purchase or payment for public lands issued by the receiver of the land office, shall be entitled to record under this chapter, and the record of all instruments or other documents shall have the same effect to all intents and purposes as though the same were acknowledged and otherwise executed as required by the provisions of this chapter relating to conveyances.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 14; R.S. 1887, § 17; Laws 1890, ch. 76, § 1; R.S. 1899, § 2761; C.S. 1910, § 3653; C.S. 1920, § 4609; R.S. 1931, § 97-134; C.S. 1945, § 66-116; W.S. 1957, § 34-21; Laws 1961, ch. 156, § 1; 1973, ch. 39, § 1; 1995, ch. 158, § 1; 2009, ch. 168, § 206.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, substituted “county clerk” for “register of deeds (county clerk)” in (a).

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Condominium assessment lien binds subsequent mortgagee interest. —

A condominium association's lien for assessments was a contractual lien which related back to the time that the condominium declaration was recorded and, as a covenant running with the land, bound the holders and assignees of a subsequent mortgagee interest. American Holidays, Inc. v. Foxtail Owners Ass'n, 821 P.2d 577, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 184 (Wyo. 1991).

Constructive notice by recording is a matter entirely dependent upon statute. Torgeson v. Connelly, 348 P.2d 63, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1959) sub. nom.Markey v. Connelly, 367 P.2d 964, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 58 (Wyo. 1962).

Duty to search record. —

In action for specific performance of contract whereby defendant agreed to buy of plaintiff all interest of plaintiff in property, consisting of first mortgage on land properly foreclosed, and on which period of exercise of right of redemption was running, defendant was not entitled to escape liability on ground that there was bilateral mistake of fact as to subject matter of contract which induced agreement, because subordinate judgment lienholders had obtained sheriff's deed to property, in view of evidence that certificate of sale in favor of such lienholders was of record, but defendant made no search of record, and that such lienholder did not redeem from plaintiff's first mortgage. Paul v. Harris, 40 Wyo. 261, 276 P. 444, 1929 Wyo. LEXIS 30 (Wyo. 1929).

A subsequent purchaser for value has constructive notice of any burden upon title from the date of recordation. Crozier v. Malone, 366 P.2d 125, 1961 Wyo. LEXIS 131 (Wyo. 1961).

The filing or leaving of a conveyance in any office other than that of the register of deeds cannot constitute constructive notice. Torgeson v. Connelly, 348 P.2d 63, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1959) sub. nom.Markey v. Connelly, 367 P.2d 964, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 58 (Wyo. 1962).

Nor can recordation of an unrecordable instrument. —

An escrow agreement, although not recordable because unacknowledged, does not become recordable by purchaser's attachment to it of his acknowledged description and, when recorded, does not constitute constructive notice to subsequent purchasers of initial purchaser's interest. Low v. Sanger, 478 P.2d 60, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 214 (Wyo. 1970).

Failure to record executory contract for sale or purchase of land. —

It is true that an executory contract for the sale or purchase of land is not by statute required to be recorded, and therefore, failure to record such an instrument does not vitiate it as to subsequent purchasers — interests thus engendered being determined according to general principles of law and equity, which give weight to numerous common-law maxims, including the one that, “he who is first in time has the better right.” However, the mere chronology of transactions is not sufficient to bring such principles to play in favor of a defendant. Low v. Sanger, 478 P.2d 60, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 214 (Wyo. 1970).

No collateral attack on unrecorded deed executed before bankruptcy. —

There being no subsequent purchaser in good faith before the court, a deed conveying Wyoming land, executed more than 4 months before bankruptcy petition, was filed, though not recorded, was not subject to attack as preferential under Bankruptcy Act. Hoshaw v. Cosgriff, 247 F. 22, 1917 U.S. App. LEXIS 1630 (8th Cir. Wyo. 1917).

Priority of assignments.—

When separate interests in the same parcel were assigned to a bank and to another assignee, the bank's recording of the bank's interest before the recording of the other assignee's interest did not give the bank's assignment precedence because the recording statute did not transform two separate interests in property into one. Halling v. Yovanovich, 2017 WY 28, 391 P.3d 611, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo. 2017).

Doctrine of bona fide purchaser applies even when deed's original grantor alleges incompetence. Such a deed is voidable, not void. As against voidable deeds, the protections granted under the doctrine of bona fide purchaser are complete and apply regardless of the state of the grantor's competence, so long as the purchaser had no notice of the claimed incompetence. First Interstate Bank v. First Wyo. Bank, N.A., 762 P.2d 379, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 134 (Wyo. 1988).

A subsequent mortgagee has constructive notice of prior recorded liens and is not entitled to equitable subrogation. —

District court properly granted summary judgment to a bank in a mortgage foreclosure action because it would have been improper to apply the doctrine of equitable subrogation to allow a refinancing mortgagee to be subrogated to the priority lien position held by an original mortgagee as this statute was clearly a filing date priority statute and the refinancing mortgagee, which was considered a purchaser under W.S. § 34-1-101, had constructive notice of a prior lien held by a bank. Countrywide Home Loans, Inc. v. First Nat'l Bank of Steamboat Springs, 2006 WY 132, 144 P.3d 1224, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 146 (2006).

Applied in

Elliott v. Sioux Oil Co., 191 F. Supp. 847, 1960 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 5108 (D. Wyo. 1960); Bowers Welding & Hotshot, Inc. v. Bromley, 699 P.2d 299, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 480 (Wyo. 1985); Marple v. Wyoming Prod. Credit Ass'n, 750 P.2d 1315, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1988); River Props. Pshp. v. Willoughby, 944 P.2d 1145, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 120 (Wyo. 1997).

Quoted in

Dame v. Mileski, 80 Wyo. 156, 340 P.2d 205, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 33 (1959); Wyoming Dep't of Revenue & Taxation-Excise Tax Div. v. First Wyo. Bank, 718 P.2d 31, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 540 (Wyo. 1986); Newman v. American Nat'l Bank, 780 P.2d 336, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 207 (Wyo. 1989); Esterholdt v. Pacificorp, 2013 WY 64, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 68 (May 22, 2013).

Cited in

Hawkins v. Stoffers, 40 Wyo. 226, 276 P. 452, 1929 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (1929); Barnhart Drilling Co. v. Petroleum Fin., Inc., 807 P.2d 411, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1991).

Law reviews. —

See “Recording the Land Contract,” 6 Wyo. L.J. 208.

See note, “Recording Federal Oil and Gas Leases,” 15 Wyo. L.J. 237 (1961).

See comment, “Subsidence Regulations,” VI Land & Water L. Rev. 543 (1971).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Record of instrument which comprises or includes interest of or right that is not a proper subject of record, 3 ALR2d 577.

Regulations as to filing or recording of subdivision maps or plats, 11 ALR2d 524.

Personal covenant in recorded deed as enforceable against grantee, lessee or successor, 23 ALR2d 520.

Necessity that mortgage covering oil and gas lease be recorded as real estate mortgage and/or filed or recorded as chattel mortgage, 34 ALR2d 902.

Reinstatement and restoration of mortgages released or discharged without authorization, as against subsequent purchasers, lienholders, judgment creditors, and the like, without notice, 35 ALR2d 948.

Record of instrument without sufficient acknowledgment as notice, 59 ALR2d 1299.

Solid mineral royalty as real or personal property for recording purposes, 68 ALR2d 732.

Record of incorrect instrument as notice of intended contents, 79 ALR2d 1180.

Reformation as against third person of instrument mistakenly describing property as affected by its record, 79 ALR2d 1180.

Reformation as against third person of instrument mistakenly describing property as affected by its record, 79 ALR2d 1180.

Record of instrument incorrectly describing property as notice of intended contents affecting right to reformation of instrument, 79 ALR2d 1180.

Sufficiency of designation of taxpayer in recorded notice of federal tax lien, 3 ALR3d 633.

Recorded real property instrument as charging third party with constructive notice of provisions of extrinsic instrument referred to therein, 89 ALR3d 901.

Vendor's obligation to disclose to purchaser of land presence of contamination from hazardous substances or wastes, 12 ALR5th 630.

§ 34-1-122. Force and effect of conveyances prior to act.

All conveyances of real estate heretofore made and acknowledged or proved in accordance with the laws of this state in force at the time of such making, acknowledgment or proof, shall have the same force as evidence, and be recorded in the same manner and with like effect as conveyances executed and acknowledged in accordance with the provisions of this act.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 25; R.S. 1887, § 28; R.S. 1899, § 2758; C.S. 1910, § 3650; C.S. 1920, § 4606; R.S. 1931, § 97-131; C.S. 1945, § 66-129; W.S. 1957, § 34-22.

Meaning of “this act.” —

See note to § 34-1-101.

§ 34-1-123. Admissibility of conveyance or record thereof as evidence.

All deeds, mortgages, conveyances or instruments of any character, concerning any interest in lands within this state, which shall be executed, acknowledged, attested or proved in accordance with the provisions of this act or the laws of this state, or the local laws of any mining district wherein such real estate is situate, in force at the date of such acknowledgment, attestation or proof, may be read in evidence, without in the first instance additional proof of the execution thereof, and the record of any such deed, mortgage, conveyance or instrument, whether an original record of any mining district, or a copy thereof deposited in the register’s [county clerk’s] office of any county, in accordance with the laws of this state (as a part of the records of such mining district) or a record of such recorder’s office, when the same appears by such record to be properly acknowledged, attested or proved in accordance with the laws of this state, or of the proper mining district in force at the date of such acknowledgment, attestation or proof, or a transcript from any such record, certified by the register [county clerk] of the proper county where such deed, mortgage, conveyance or instrument ought by law to be recorded, may, upon the affidavit of the party desiring to use the same, that the original thereof is not in his possession or power to produce, be read in evidence with like effect as the original of such deed, mortgage, conveyance or instrument properly acknowledged, attested or proved as aforesaid, but the effect of such evidence may be rebutted by other competent testimony.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 17; R.S. 1887, § 20; R.S. 1899, § 2739; C.S. 1910, § 3631; C.S. 1920, § 4587; R.S. 1931, § 97-112; C.S. 1945, § 66-120; W.S. 1957, § 34-23.

Meaning of “this act.” —

See note to § 34-1-101.

Additional proof of execution not initially required. —

A power of attorney to convey lands, as well as an executory contract for sale or purchase of lands may be read in evidence without in first instance offering additional proof of execution. 16 Wyo. 161, 92 P. 624.

Tax title claimant. —

Statutory provision that the records of the clerk of county commissioners is sufficient to prove tax sale did not change rule that tax title claimant has the burden of proving that statutory provisions have been complied with. Barrett v. Barrett, 46 Wyo. 84, 23 P.2d 857, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 33 (Wyo. 1933).

Prima facie case. —

Where plaintiff introduced deed from Mrs. S. and her husband, since deceased, proved they were in possession, and filed an action wherein validity of the deed was affirmed on appeal, prima facie case was established. Atlas Realty Co. v. Rowray, 51 Wyo. 318, 65 P.2d 1122, 1937 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1937).

Cited in

First Nat'l Bank v. Citizens' State Bank, 11 Wyo. 32, 70 P. 726, 1902 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (1902).

Law reviews. —

For discussion of Fed. R. Evid. 902, which relates to self-authentication, see XII Land & Water L. Rev. 601 (1977).

§ 34-1-124. Federal land office instruments; generally; railway maps and affidavits; recording and recording fees.

Patents heretofore or hereafter issued by the United States, for lands and certificates of purchase or payment for public lands, heretofore or hereafter issued by the receiver of any land office of the United States, shall be entitled to be recorded under the provisions of this chapter, and the record of all such instruments shall have the effect to all intents and purposes, as though same were acknowledged and otherwise executed as required by law; provided, that any railroad company, having a right-of-way or station grounds, acquired in conformity to an act of the congress of the United States, requiring a map thereof, to be approved by the secretary of the interior, shall file with the county clerk, of any county in this state, wherein such right-of-way and station grounds may be, a copy of such map, duly authenticated, together with the affidavit of any officer or agent of such railroad company, describing by quarter sections the lands within such county, affected by such right-of-way, which were public lands when such map was approved, and it shall be the duty of such county clerk to record said affidavit, and file said map, and to note upon the abstract of lands of his office as to each quarter section so described, that a right-of-way across the same is claimed by the company filing said map; provided, further, that the fee for filing said map and recording said affidavit, shall be two dollars ($2.00).

History.

Laws 1890, ch. 76, §§ 1, 2; R.S. 1899, § 2757; C.S. 1910, § 3649; Laws 1911, ch. 91, § 1; C.S. 1920, § 4605; R.S. 1931, § 97-130; C.S. 1945, § 66-117; W.S. 1957, § 34-24; Laws 2009, ch. 168, § 206.

Cross references. —

As to filing plats of lands obtained from state by railroads, see § 37-9-203.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, substituted “county clerk” for “register of deeds” throughout the section.

Law reviews. —

See “Record of Mineral Reservations in Patent,” 12 Wyo. L.J. 151 (1958).

§ 34-1-125. Federal land office instruments; as evidence.

The certificate of purchase or payment issued by the receiver of any land office of the United States, or the record thereof, or if the same be lost or destroyed or beyond the reach of the person entitled thereto, secondary evidence of its contents, is proof of the title to the lands described therein, equivalent to a patent against all except the United States or the holder of a patent from the United States.

History.

Laws 1890, ch. 76, § 3; R.S. 1899, § 2740; C.S. 1910, § 3632; C.S. 1920, § 4588; R.S. 1931, § 97-113; C.S. 1945, § 66-118; W.S. 1957, § 34-25.

Cited in

Muir v. Bosey, 23 Wyo. 46, 146 P. 595, 1915 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (1915).

§ 34-1-126. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2008, ch. 20, § 3.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 26, related to liability of county clerks for recording improperly executed conveyances.

§ 34-1-127. Effect on purported absolute conveyance of unrecorded deed of defeasance.

When a deed or mortgage purports to be an absolute conveyance in terms, but is made or intended to be made defeasible by force of defeasance, or other instrument for that purpose, the original conveyance shall not be thereby defeated or affected as against any person other than the maker of the defeasance, or his heirs or devisees, or persons having actual notice thereof, unless the instrument of defeasance shall have been recorded in the office of the county clerk of the county where the lands lie.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 18; R.S. 1887, § 21; R.S. 1899, § 2763; C.S. 1910, § 3655; C.S. 1920, § 4611; R.S. 1931, § 97-136; C.S. 1945, § 66-121; W.S. 1957, § 34-27; Laws 2009, ch. 168, § 206.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, substituted “county clerk” for “register of deeds.”

Quoted in

Gheen v. State ex rel. Dep't of Health, 2014 WY 70, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 75 (May 30, 2014).

Applied in

Marple v. Wyoming Prod. Credit Ass'n, 750 P.2d 1315, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1988).

Cited in

Hein v. Lee, 549 P.2d 286, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 184 (Wyo. 1976).

§ 34-1-128. Recorded assignment of mortgage.

The recording of the assignment of a mortgage, shall not in itself, be deemed notice of such assignment to the mortgagor, his heirs or personal representatives, so as to invalidate any payment made by them or either of them to the mortgagee.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 19; R.S. 1887, § 22; R.S. 1899, § 2764; C.S. 1910, § 3656; C.S. 1920, § 4612; R.S. 1931, § 97-137; C.S. 1945, § 66-122; W.S. 1957, § 34-28.

Cross references. —

As to necessity of recording assignment of mortgage with reference to foreclosure and power of sale, see § 34-4-103.

§ 34-1-129. Husband or wife may appoint each other as attorney-in-fact to control interests.

A husband or wife may constitute the other his or her attorney-in-fact to control or dispose of his or her property, or any inchoate or other interest therein and may revoke the same to the same extent and in the same manner as other persons.

History.

Laws 1888, ch. 75, § 2; R.S. 1899, § 2738; C.S. 1910, § 3630; C.S. 1920, § 4586; R.S. 1931, § 97-111; C.S. 1945, § 66-126; W.S. 1957, § 34-29.

Cross references. —

For provisions authorizing wife to release and convey her interest in realty, see §§ 34-1-108, 34-1-109.

As to rights and liabilities of married persons generally, see §§ 20-1-201, 20-1-202.

§ 34-1-130. County clerk to discharge mortgage or deed of trust on record when certificate of release recorded.

Any mortgage or deed of trust shall be discharged upon the record thereof, by the county clerk in whose custody it shall be, or in whose office it is recorded, when there shall be recorded in his office a certificate or deed of release executed by the mortgagee, trustee or beneficiary, his assignee or legally authorized representative, or by a title agent or title insurer acting in accordance with the provisions of W.S. 34-1-145 through 34-1-150, acknowledged or proven and certified as by law prescribed to entitle conveyances to be recorded, specifying that such mortgage or deed of trust has been paid or otherwise satisfied or discharged, and the county clerk shall make a reference to such release in the record.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 28; 1890, ch. 6, § 1; R.S. 1899, § 2800; C.S. 1910, § 3692; C.S. 1920, § 4650; R.S. 1931, § 71-222; C.S. 1945, § 66-132; W.S. 1957, § 34-31; Laws 1999, ch. 84, § 2; 2019, ch. 3, § 1.

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, in the last sentence, substituted “in” for “upon the margin of,” and deleted “of the mortgage or trust deed.”

No consideration for quitclaim deed. —

Finding of no consideration for quitclaim deed executed by mortgagee on day purchaser of land assumed to pay mortgage held proper. Chesney v. Valley Live Stock Co., 34 Wyo. 378, 244 P. 216, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (Wyo. 1926).

And mortgage not released. —

Quitclaim deed from mortgagee to assignee of mortgagor will not operate as release of mortgage if not so intended. Chesney v. Valley Live Stock Co., 34 Wyo. 378, 244 P. 216, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (Wyo. 1926).

Failure to record release. —

Because a debtor's note was set-off against her obligation to a limited liability company (LLC) as allowed by Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 1-15-417, the note was satisfied and a mortgage terminated at the time the LLC answered a creditor's writ of garnishment. As the debtor did not file her petition until after that date, the mortgage was not property of the estate, regardless of the fact that the LLC did not file a cancellation form or discharge as required under Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 34-2-113 and 34-1-130, and thus, the creditor did not violate the automatic stay by seeking to foreclose on the LLC's property. In re Ford, 2013 Bankr. LEXIS 179 (Bankr. D. Wyo. Jan. 16, 2013).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Requiring security as condition of cancelling of record mortgage or lien or of recording payment, 2 ALR2d 1064.

Agreement by mortgagee for partial release of mortgage as enduring in favor of mortgagors or against mortgagee's privies, 41 ALR3d 7.

Construction of provision in real estate mortgage, land contract, or other security instrument for release of separate parcels of land as payments are made, 41 ALR3d 7.

§ 34-1-131. Force and effect of section 34-1-130 on mortgages and deeds of trust executed and deeds of trust discharged prior to act.

The preceding section [§ 34-1-130], as hereby amended, shall apply to all mortgages and deeds of trust, heretofore as well as those which may be hereafter, executed and the release or discharge of any deed of trust heretofore made in accordance with said section, by the trustee named in said deed of trust or his successor, is hereby legalized and declared to be as binding upon all parties in interest as though such release or discharge had been made after the passage of this act [§§ 34-1-130, 34-1-131].

History.

Laws 1890, ch. 6, § 2; R.S. 1899, § 2801; C.S. 1910, § 3693; C.S. 1920, § 4651; R.S. 1931, § 71-223; C.S. 1945, § 66-133; W.S. 1957, § 34-32.

Editor's notes. —

Section 3, ch. 6, Laws 1890, makes the act effective from and after passage. Approved February 13, 1890.

§ 34-1-132. Liability of mortgagee for failing to discharge; damage limitations; definition.

  1. A mortgagee shall, within thirty (30) days after having received by certified or registered mail a request in writing for the discharge or release of a mortgage, execute and acknowledge a certificate or deed of discharge or release of the mortgage if there has been full performance of the condition of the mortgage and if there is no other written agreement between the mortgagee and mortgagor encumbering the property subject to the mortgage.
  2. A mortgagee who fails or refuses to discharge or release a mortgage within the thirty (30) day period required by subsection (a) of this section is liable to the mortgagor or his assignees for:
    1. All actual damages resulting from the mortgagee’s failure or refusal to discharge or release the mortgage; and
    2. Special damages in the amount of one-tenth of one percent (.10%) of the original principal amount of the mortgage for each additional day after the thirty (30) day period until the mortgage is released or discharged. Special damages authorized by this paragraph shall not exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day.
  3. Notwithstanding any assignment of the mortgage, the mortgagee of record is liable for the damages specified in subsection (b) of this section unless, within sixty (60) days after receipt of the request for discharge or release as provided by subsection (a) of this section, he furnishes to the person making the request the name and address of the current assignee or holder of the mortgage who has legal authority to execute the discharge or release.
  4. As used in this section “mortgagee” means the mortgagee named in the original mortgage or, if assigned, the current holder of the mortgage or the servicing agent for the current holder of the mortgage.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 1, § 29; R.S. 1887, § 32; R.S. 1899, § 2804; C.S. 1910, § 3696; C.S. 1920, § 4654; R.S. 1931, § 71-226; C.S. 1945, § 66-134; W.S. 1957, § 34-33; Laws 1989, ch. 63, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

Chapter 1, Laws 1882, contained a § 30 which read: “All words in this act importing the singular number may be construed as meaning the plural, and those importing the plural may be construed as meaning the singular, and all words importing the masculine gender may be construed as meaning females.”

Prior compilers omitted this section.

Repealing clauses. —

Section 31, ch. 1, Laws 1882, reads: “Chapter 3 of the Compiled Laws being an act concerning alienation by deed and for other purposes, and chapter 40 of the Compiled Laws being an act to provide for the recording of deeds, mortgages, etc., and chapter 23 of the Session Laws of 1879 being an act concerning alienation by deed and for other purposes, and all other acts or parts of acts inconsistent with or in conflict with this act be and the same are hereby repealed.”

Failure to discharge not found. —

There was no failure to discharge a mortgage in violation of the statute since letters provided by the mortgagor evidenced merely an offer to render full performance where the letters stated that the mortgagor stood “ready to pay off the entire principal and interest due” on the mortgage and that a bank “can close the loan … and the funds would be available immediately, as long as there is a release of mortgage.” Hansen v. Little Bear Inn Co., 9 P.3d 960, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 165 (Wyo. 2000).

Damages not allowed when service is by publication. —

Where mortgagee was served only by publication, though her attorney who received payment was made a party defendant, no judgment for the penalty prescribed by this section could be allowed for the mortgagee's failure to cancel mortgage. Cadle v. McLimans, 23 Wyo. 515, 153 P. 901, 1915 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Wyo. 1915).

Cited in

Johnson v. Smith, 455 P.2d 244, 1969 Wyo. LEXIS 137 (Wyo. 1969).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Trustee's duty and liability as to release of mortgage, or deed of trust, 90 ALR2d 501.

Damages recoverable for real-estate mortgagee's refusal to discharge mortgage or give partial release therefrom, 8 ALR4th 853.

Construction mortgagee-lender's duty to protect interest of subordinated purchase-money mortgagee, 13 ALR5th 684.

§ 34-1-133. Release; mortgage of deceased nonresident mortgagee.

Whenever any nonresident of this state shall die without this state, owing, at the time of his death, debts secured by mortgage or other incumbrance upon real or personal property situated in this state, and the debtor shall make voluntary payment of such debt to the executor of the last will and testament of such deceased person, or to the administrator of the estate of such deceased person, whose letters testamentary or of administration, as the case may be, were issued from the proper court of the state or territory of the United States, where such deceased creditor resided at the time of his death, it shall be lawful and competent for such executor or administrator to execute a full and valid release, and acquittance of such debt, and of the mortgage or other incumbrance securing the same; provided, that there shall be attached to such release and acquittance, and made a part thereof, a full and complete transcript of the records of the court issuing such letters testamentary or of administration, as the case may be, certified to by the clerk of such court, or other proper custodian of the records thereof, under his hand and under the seal of such court, fully exhibiting the due appointment and qualification of such executor or administrator, and there shall also be attached to such release and made a part thereof, a certificate under the hand of the presiding judge of such court, or the clerk thereof, that at the date of such release, the person or persons executing the same, was such duly appointed and qualified executor or administrator, as set forth in such release. Any release so executed shall be admitted to record, in this state, in the office of any of the county clerks and upon being recorded in the proper office, the county clerk shall discharge the mortgage or other incumbrance in such release mentioned, in the manner provided by law, but this section shall not be construed to authorize any administrator appointed by the courts of any other state or territory of the United States, to exercise any power, within the state other than the power to receive voluntary payments of debts due to his intestate, and to release mortgages or other incumbrances upon property situate in this state and securing such debts.

History.

Laws 1890-91, ch. 26, §§ 1, 2; R.S. 1899, § 2802; C.S. 1910, § 3694; C.S. 1920, § 4652; R.S. 1931, § 71-224; C.S. 1945, § 66-135; W.S. 1957, § 34-34; Laws 2009, ch. 168, § 206.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in the second sentence, deleted “and ex officio register of deeds” following “any of the county clerks” and substituted “county clerk” for “register of deeds” preceding “shall discharge the mortgage.”

Cited in

Security-First Nat'l Bank v. King, 46 Wyo. 59, 23 P.2d 851, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 32, 90 A.L.R. 125 (1933).

Law reviews. —
