Retaliatory eviction of tenant for reporting landlord's violation of law, 23 ALR5th 140.

Discharge of mortgage and taking back of new mortgage as affecting lien intervening between old and new mortgages, 43 ALR5th 519.

Admiralty jurisdiction of federal district courts under provisions of Ship Mortgage Act (46 USC § 954) authorizing in personam admiralty suits on default of ship mortgages, 72 ALR Fed 578.

When is eviction of tenant by private landlord conducted “under color of state law” for purposes of 42 USC § 1983, 73 ALR Fed 78.

Right of mortgagee and/or lienor to compensation when property subject to mortgage and/or lien is taken by federal governmental forfeiture based on criminal acts of owner, 136 ALR Fed 593.

26A C.J.S. Deeds § 1 et seq.; 59 C.J.S. Mortgages § 1 et seq.

§ 34-2-101. Word “heirs” or other words of inheritance not necessary to convey fee simple; presumptions.

The term “heirs”, or other words of inheritance, shall not be necessary to create or convey an estate in fee simple, and every conveyance of real estate shall pass all the estate of the grantor therein, unless the intent to pass a less estate shall expressly appear or be necessarily implied in the terms of the grant.

History.

Laws 1884, ch. 5, § 1; R.S. 1887, § 34; R.S. 1899, § 2737; C.S. 1910, § 3629; C.S. 1920, § 4585; R.S. 1931, § 97-110; C.S. 1945, § 66-127; W.S. 1957, § 34-41.

Cross references. —

As to a provision that the acknowledgment and recording of plats in connection with laying out townsites shall be equivalent to a deed in fee simple, etc., see § 34-12-104.

Right of way.—

Given the definition of right of way in 1910, it would have been unusual for someone in 1913 to believe the grant of a right of way meant a fee-simple conveyance, and instead, the drafter would have considered a conveyance of a right of way to grant only an easement; construing the deeds against the drafter and giving right of way its plain meaning as understood in 1913, the deeds at issue conveyed only a limited grant and indicated that the grantor conveyed a right of way, which meant an easement in 1913. Burlington Northern Santa Fe Ry. v. Box Creek Mineral Ltd. P'ship, 2018 WY 67, 420 P.3d 161, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 71 (Wyo. 2018).

This section applies to a reservation of an easement for a private way which is equivalent to a conveyance thereof. Forde v. Libby, 22 Wyo. 464, 143 P. 1190, 1914 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1914).

Applicability of rule in Shelley's Case. —

See Crawford v. Barber, 385 P.2d 655, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 114 (Wyo. 1963).

Where no automatic expiration, no fee simple determinable. —

The plain language in a deed, stating that the grantors conveyed the land for the purpose of constructing a county hospital, did not clearly state that the estate conveyed would expire automatically if the land was not used for the stated purpose. As such, it did not evidence an intent of the grantors to convey a fee simple determinable. Wood v. Board of County Comm'rs, 759 P.2d 1250, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 108 (Wyo. 1988).

Where no power to reenter, no condition subsequent. —

The plain language of a deed, while articulating that the land conveyed was to be used for a county hospital, did not clearly state an intent of the grantors to retain a discretionary power to reenter the land if the land ceased to be used for the stated purpose. Therefore, the grantors did not convey a fee simple subject to a condition subsequent. Wood v. Board of County Comm'rs, 759 P.2d 1250, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 108 (Wyo. 1988).

Creation of easement.

Deed from the original owners' widows did not create an easement appurtenant to the lands west of the railroad right-of-way; under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 34-2-101, it was a fee simple conveyance, and the widows passed the entire estate in fee simple as their intent to pass a lesser intent did not expressly appear in the deed, nor was it implied. Thornock v. Esterholdt, 2013 WY 42, 299 P.3d 68, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Wyo. 2013).

Applied in

McGinnis v. McGinnis, 391 P.2d 927, 1964 Wyo. LEXIS 96 (Wyo. 1964).

Law reviews. —

See article, “Fee Royalty Conveyancing in Wyoming,” II Land & Water L. Rev. 117 (1967).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Nature of estates or interests created by grant or devise to one and heirs if donee should have any heirs, 16 ALR2d 670.

Postponing or limiting the rights of grantee until after death of grantor as affecting validity of instrument in form of deed, 31 ALR2d 532.

Description in antecedent contract of land to be conveyed as merged in, or superseded by, deed, 38 ALR2d 1310.

Character of tenancy created by instrument purporting to convey one's own title or interest to himself and another, 44 ALR2d 595.

Character of tenancy created by owner's conveyance to himself and another, or to another alone, of an undivided interest, 44 ALR2d 595.

Delivery as essential to gift by deed, 48 ALR2d 1405.

Conflict between granting and habendum clauses as to estate conveyed, 58 ALR2d 1374.

Delivery of a deed without manual transfer or record, 87 ALR2d 787.

Necessity of parting with control in case of delivery of deed without manual transfer or record, 87 ALR2d 787.

Estate created by deed to one and “blood heirs” or “blooded heirs,” 89 ALR2d 1222.

§ 34-2-102. Form of warranty deed.

Conveyances of land may be substantially in the following form:

Warranty Deed. A. B., grantor, (here insert name or names and place of residence), for and in consideration of (here insert consideration) in hand paid, conveys and warrants to C. D., grantee, (here insert grantee's name or names and place of residence) the following described real estate (here insert description) situate in the county of , state of Wyoming. Dated this day of A.D. A.B.

Click to view

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 93, § 1; R.S. 1899, § 2766; C.S. 1910, § 3658; C.S. 1920, § 4615; R.S. 1931, § 97-201; C.S. 1945, § 66-201; W.S. 1957, § 34-42.

Cross references. —

As to information to be shown in deed, and as to form of deed with reference to real property sold under mortgage or execution, see § 1-18-109 et seq.

As to required words for waiver of homestead exemptions, see § 34-2-121.

Covenants. —

Where two brother agreed to partition their ranch and agreed that, if a railway right-of-way traversing their ranch was ever abandoned, they would execute any necessary documents to vest the other with full title in the right-of-way over his respective portion, where years later, one brother purchased the right-of-way but his successors (defendants) refused to execute documents to fully vest the second brother's successors (plaintiffs) with title to the right of way over their portion, and where plaintiffs filed suit seeking specific performance, the district court erred in entering summary judgment for defendants because the unambiguous contractual language required defendants, as the first brother's successors, to convey whatever interest they received in the right of way over the second brother's land to plaintiffs, the second brother's successors. The brothers' agreement reflected in the warranty deeds unambiguously reflected an intent to cross-convey all of the interest the brothers owned in the land within the right-of-way to the brother who received the adjacent property as part of the partition and cross-conveyance of the entire ranch. Davidson Land Co., LLC v. Davidson, 2011 WY 29, 247 P.3d 67, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 2011).

Quoted in

Bakken v. Price, 613 P.2d 1222, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 286 (Wyo. 1980).

Cited in

United States v. Northern Pac. Ry., 169 F. Supp. 735, 1959 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 3874 (D. Wyo. 1959).

§ 34-2-103. Form of warranty deed; effect; implied covenants.

Every deed in substance in the above form [§ 34-2-102], when otherwise duly executed, shall be deemed and held a conveyance in fee simple, to the grantee, his heirs and assigns, with covenants on the part of the grantor, (a) that at the time of the making and delivery of such deed he was lawfully seized of an indefeasible estate in fee simple in and to the premises therein described, and had good right and power to convey the same; (b) that the same were then free from all incumbrances; and (c) that he warrants to the grantee, his heirs and assigns, the quiet and peaceful possession of such premises, and will defend the title thereto against all persons who may lawfully claim the same. And such covenants shall be obligatory upon the grantor, his heirs and personal representatives, as fully, and with like effect as if written at length in such deed.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 93, § 1, 2nd par.; R.S. 1899, § 2767; C.S. 1910, § 3659; C.S. 1920, § 4616; R.S. 1931, § 97-202; C.S. 1945, § 66-202; W.S. 1957, § 34-43.

Cross references. —

See also §§ 34-1-135, 34-1-136, as to implied covenants.

Mortgage lien an encumbrance. —

Mortgage lien constituted an encumbrance on property, and purchasers were entitled to seek redress from sellers for breach of implied covenants in warranty deed, since purchasers suffered a constructive eviction when they rightfully yielded to mortgagee's paramount title. Patel v. Khan, 970 P.2d 836, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 176 (Wyo. 1998).

Breach of warranty action prohibited. —

Where the grantee is a co-tenant and thus the owner of the outstanding interest, that interest must be subtracted from the interest purportedly warranted by the grantor; a grantee may not bring an action for breach of warranty where he owns the outstanding interest that the grantor is alleged to have warranted. Gilstrap v. June Eisele Warren Trust, 2005 WY 21, 106 P.3d 858, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 2005).

Common grazing rights rendered summary judgment inappropriate. —

Grant of summary judgment in favor of the sellers of a ranch in the buyer's action for breach of contract and breach of warranty deed was improper because the sales contract and the warranty deed stated that the property was to be free from all encumbrances, but there were common grazing rights enforceable against the buyer, Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 34-2-103(b). Along with other material facts, the extent to which those rights encumbered the property was a question of material fact that had yet to be determined. Foxley & Co. v. Ellis, 2009 WY 16, 201 P.3d 425, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 2009).

Quoted in

Bakken v. Price, 613 P.2d 1222, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 286 (Wyo. 1980); Gheen v. State ex rel. Dep't of Health, 2014 WY 70, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 75 (May 30, 2014).

Cited in

United States v. Northern Pac. Ry., 169 F. Supp. 735, 1959 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 3874 (D. Wyo. 1959).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Measure and elements of damages recoverable from vendor where there has been mistake as to amount of land conveyed, 94 ALR3d 1091.

§ 34-2-104. Form of quitclaim deed.

Quitclaim may be in substance in the following form:

Quitclaim Deed. A. B., grantor (here insert grantor's name or names, and place of residence) for the consideration of (here insert consideration) conveys and quitclaims to (here insert grantee's name or names) all interest in the following described real estate, (here insert description) situate in the county of , in the state of Wyoming. Dated this day of A.D. A.B.

Click to view

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 93, § 2; R.S. 1899, § 2768; C.S. 1910, § 3660; C.S. 1920, § 4617; R.S. 1931, § 97-203; C.S. 1945, § 66-203; W.S. 1957, § 34-44.

Cross references. —

As to quitclaim deeds generally, see § 34-1-107.

As to required words for waiver of homestead exemptions, see § 34-2-121.

“Grant, bargain, sell” not quitclaim. —

Deed executed by entryman who had filed application for oil and gas prospecting permit, conveying undivided interest in oil and gas and other minerals, containing words “grant, bargain, sell,” is a deed of bargain and sale, not conveying merely grantor's interest in property, but the property itself, and is not a “quitclaim deed.” Tendolle v. Eureka Oil Syndicate, 38 Wyo. 442, 268 P. 185, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 63 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 38 Wyo. 442, 270 P. 542, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 64 (Wyo. 1928); Walliker v. Escott, 608 P.2d 1272, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 250 (Wyo. 1980).

Perfecting of grantor's legal title and grantee's interest. —

When a grantor who does not possess legal title quitclaims his entire interest in a piece of real property, the grantee cannot then expect that such a grant carries with it the implication that grantor has retained an equitable interest capable of ripening into legal title from which the grantee will then be permitted to claim; but when an entryman quitclaims a portion of a mineral estate, while retaining an equitable interest in the surface estate, it is then logical for the grantee to expect that the grantor will later perfect legal title and thus perfect the grantee's mineral interest. Walliker v. Escott, 608 P.2d 1272, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 250 (Wyo. 1980).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Estoppel by Deed, Partial Quitclaims, Walliker v. Escott, 608 P.2d 1272, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 250 (Wyo. 1980),” see XVI Land & Water L. Rev. 269 (1981).

§ 34-2-105. Form of quitclaim deed; effect generally.

Every deed in substance in the form prescribed in the foregoing section [§ 34-2-104], when otherwise duly executed, shall be deemed and held a sufficient conveyance, release and quitclaim to the grantee, his heirs and assigns, in fee of all the then existing legal or equitable rights of the grantor in the premises therein described, but shall not extend to after acquired title unless words are added expressing such intention.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 93, § 2, 2nd par.; R.S. 1899, § 2769; C.S. 1910, § 3661; C.S. 1920, § 4618; R.S. 1931, § 97-204; C.S. 1945, § 66-204; W.S. 1957, § 34-45.

Cross references. —

For another provision concerning effect of quitclaim deeds, see § 34-1-107.

As to execution of quitclaim deed in connection with sale of lands and improvements known as and included in Saratoga Hot Springs reserve, see § 36-8-404.

History of section. —

This section is a part of § 2 of ch. 93, Laws 1895, but was set out as a separate section by prior compilers.

Because of the compilation of the statute as separate sections, the words “the foregoing” were substituted for the original word “this” in the first sentence.

Perfecting of grantor's legal title and grantee's interest. —

When a grantor who does not possess legal title quitclaims his entire interest in a piece of real property, the grantee cannot then expect that such a grant carries with it the implication that grantor has retained an equitable interest capable of ripening into legal title from which the grantee will then be permitted to claim; but when an entryman quitclaims a portion of a mineral estate, while retaining an equitable interest in the surface estate, it is then logical for the grantee to expect that the grantor will later perfect legal title and thus perfect the grantee's mineral interest. Walliker v. Escott, 608 P.2d 1272, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 250 (Wyo. 1980).

Valid transfer of royalty interests. —

That royalty interests in oil and gas permit were transferred when permit had expired and before renewal was granted did not invalidate transfer. Rue v. Merrill, 42 Wyo. 511, 297 P. 379, 1931 Wyo. LEXIS 53 (Wyo. 1931).

Quoted in

Davidson Land Co., Llc v. Davidson, 2011 WY 29, 247 P.3d 67, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Feb. 18, 2011); Gheen v. State ex rel. Dep't of Health, 2014 WY 70, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 75 (May 30, 2014).

Cited in

Tendolle v. Eureka Oil Syndicate, 38 Wyo. 442, 268 P. 185, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 63 (1928).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Estoppel by Deed, Partial Quitclaims, Walliker v. Escott, 608 P.2d 1272, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 250 (Wyo. 1980),” see XVI Land & Water L. Rev. 269 (1981).

§ 34-2-106. Form of quitclaim deed; effect without word “release”.

A deed of quitclaim, without the use of the word “release” shall be sufficient to pass all the estate which the grantor could lawfully convey by deed of bargain and sale. And all deeds of quitclaim, heretofore given to real estate in this state, shall have the same effect as deeds of quitclaim and release and shall operate the same as if the word “release” had been used therein.

History.

Laws 1884, ch. 5, § 2; R.S. 1887, § 35; R.S. 1899, § 2771; C.S. 1910, § 3663; C.S. 1920, § 4620; R.S. 1931, § 97-206; C.S. 1945, § 66-218; W.S. 1957, § 34-46.

§ 34-2-107. Form of real estate mortgage.

Mortgages of land may be in the following form:

A. B., mortgagor, (here insert the name or names and place of residence) to secure the payment of (here insert the amount of indebtedness, when due, rate of interest, and whether secured by a note or otherwise), do hereby mortgage the following described real estate (here insert description thereof) situate in county, state of Wyoming. The mortgagor agrees to pay all taxes and assessments on said premises and to keep the buildings thereon insured in a sum not less than $ during the life of this mortgage, payable to the mortgagee; and in case he does not the mortgagee may insure said building or buildings and pay said taxes and all amounts so paid shall be added to and considered as part of the above indebtedness hereby secured. In case of default of payment of either interest or principal then the whole indebtedness herein secured shall become due and payable, and the mortgagee may proceed, pursuant to law, to foreclose on said property and in case of foreclosure the mortgagor hereby agrees to pay all costs of the same, including an attorney's fee of $ Dated this day of A.D. A.B.

Click to view

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 93, § 3; R.S. 1899, § 2774; C.S. 1910, § 3666; C.S. 1920, § 4623; R.S. 1931, § 71-201; C.S. 1945, § 66-205; W.S. 1957, § 34-46.

Cross references. —

As to master form mortgages generally, see §§ 34-2-109 to 34-2-112.

As to required words for waiver of homestead exemptions, see § 34-2-121.

As to form of deeds of trust, see § 34-3-101.

Mortgage superior to general lien and homestead right. —

A mortgage executed by a grantee to a third person as security for money loaned for paying the purchase price of a homestead, as well as a purchase money mortgage executed to the grantor, has, in equity, precedence over any prior general lien, and is superior to the homestead right of the mortgagor, without any statutory provision therefor, and it is immaterial that the wife or husband of the grantee did not join in the execution of the mortgage or that the right of homestead is not expressly waived or released by a recital to that effect in the mortgage or in the certificate of acknowledgment. Powers v. Pense, 20 Wyo. 327, 123 P. 925, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 1912).

And rights of first mortgagee not affected by accepting third mortgage. —

Acceptance by first mortgagee of a third mortgage including the amount due on the first mortgage did not, in absence of agreement to the contrary, discharge the lien of first mortgage, and first mortgagee continued to hold first and third liens on the property, unaffected by decree foreclosing the second mortgage in an action to which he was not a party. Bolln v. La Prele Live Stock Co., 27 Wyo. 335, 196 P. 748, 1921 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 1921).

Mortgage upheld when mistake made in attestation. —

Where by mistake there was but one attesting witness to a mortgage, instead of two, as required by law, and mortgage provided that on default mortgagee could take possession and sell “at public auction in manner provided by law,” there being no provision in the territorial statutes for “manner” of sale, equity would relieve the mortgagee. Jubb v. Thorpe, 1 Wyo. 356, 1877 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 1877).

Or legal consideration separable from illegal. —

When consideration of a mortgage consists of several transactions, some legal and some not, and they may be separated, the mortgage may be upheld for the legal consideration. Conradt v. Lepper, 13 Wyo. 473, 81 P. 307, 1905 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 13 Wyo. 473, 81 P. 307, 1905 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1905).

Or description of land by abbreviations. —

Mortgage description, describing land entirely by abbreviations, instead of words, to designate the portions of sections, and failing to state whether township was north or south is sufficient under evidence showing that all land in the named township in the named county was in such township north. Robinson Mercantile Co. v. Davis, 26 Wyo. 484, 187 P. 931, 1920 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1920), limited, Tendolle v. Eureka Oil Syndicate, 38 Wyo. 442, 268 P. 185, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 63 (Wyo. 1928).

Required clause for conveyance or release of homestead interest. —

Since enactment of ch. 93, Laws 1895, to make valid conveyance of homestead or to release homestead interest, it has been necessary that body of instrument and certificate of acknowledgment contain clause expressly releasing or waiving homestead right. Jones v. Losekamp, 19 Wyo. 83, 114 P. 673, 1911 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1911).

Agreement to give mortgage for amount advanced for completion of purchase price of land does not require lender to advance the entire sum needed in order to be entitled to a mortgage. Walter v. Kressman, 25 Wyo. 292, 169 P. 3, 1917 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1917).

Attorney's fees. —

Attorney's fees are chargeable under this chapter where 1 of the mortgagors has died and the claim was not presented against his estate. Delfelder v. Teton Land & Inv. Co., 46 Wyo. 142, 24 P.2d 702, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 46 Wyo. 142, 26 P.2d 153, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 1933).

Foreclosure notice not fraudulent. —

Where a mortgage foreclosure notice stated $3,500 was due as attorney's fees and only $1,250 was actually paid, it was held not fraudulent. Delfelder v. Teton Land & Inv. Co., 46 Wyo. 142, 24 P.2d 702, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 46 Wyo. 142, 26 P.2d 153, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 1933).

Mortgage clause in insurance policy. —

Insurance policy's mortgage clause, requiring mortgagee to pay premiums if mortgagor fails, was condition and not covenant on which suit could be maintained. Farnsworth v. Riverton Wyo. Ref. Co., 35 Wyo. 334, 249 P. 555, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 1926).

§ 34-2-108. Form of real estate mortgage; effect; when covenants implied.

Every such mortgage when otherwise duly executed, shall be deemed and held a good and sufficient mortgage in fee to secure the payment of the moneys therein specified; and if the same contains the words “and warrants”, the same shall be construed the same as if full covenants of seizin, good right to convey against encumbrances, of quiet enjoyment and general warranty, as expressed in section one of this act [§§ 34-2-102, 34-2-103] were fully written therein; but if the words “and warrants” are omitted no such covenant shall be implied.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 93, § 3, 2nd par.; R.S. 1899, § 2775; C.S. 1910, § 3667; C.S. 1920, § 4624; R.S. 1931, § 71-202; C.S. 1945, § 66-206; W.S. 1957, § 34-48.

Cross references. —

As to covenants generally, see §§ 34-1-135, 34-1-136.

Mortgage may be executed to copartnership. —

Mortgage executed to a copartnership is valid as against objection that it was not executed to a person or a corporation, since a mortgage merely creates a lien upon the land and does not pass title thereto. Robinson Mercantile Co. v. Davis, 26 Wyo. 484, 187 P. 931, 1920 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1920), limited, Tendolle v. Eureka Oil Syndicate, 38 Wyo. 442, 268 P. 185, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 63 (Wyo. 1928).

Acknowledgment. —

Acknowledgment is not necessary to create equitable mortgage. Harney v. Montgomery, 29 Wyo. 362, 213 P. 378, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1923).

§ 34-2-109. Master form mortgage; recording authorized; entitlement on face; need not be acknowledged.

An instrument containing a form or forms of covenants, conditions, obligations, powers, and other clauses of a mortgage may be recorded in the office of the county clerk, upon the request of any person, on tender of the lawful fees therefor, shall record the same in his registry. Every such instrument shall be entitled on the face thereof as a “Master form recorded by . . . . . (name of person causing the instrument to be recorded)”. Such instrument need not be acknowledged to be entitled to record.

History.

Laws 1967, ch. 226, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 34-48.1; Laws 2009, ch. 168, § 206.

Cross references. —

As to mortgages and deeds of trust generally, see § 34-2-107 et seq. and chapter 3 of this title, respectively.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, substituted “office of the county clerk” for “registry of deeds of any county and the recorder of such county.”

§ 34-2-110. Master form mortgage; index.

When any such instrument is recorded, the recorder shall index such instrument under the name of the person causing it to be recorded in the manner provided for miscellaneous instruments relating to real estate.

History.

Laws 1967, ch. 226, § 2; W.S. 1957, § 34-48.2.

§ 34-2-111. Master form mortgage; use by reference.

Thereafter any of the provisions of such master form instrument may be incorporated by reference in any mortgage of real estate situated within this state, if such reference in the mortgage states that the master form instrument was recorded in the county in which the mortgage is offered for record, the date when and the book and page or pages where such master form instrument was recorded, and that a copy of such master form instrument was furnished to the person executing the mortgage. The recording of any mortgage which has so incorporated by reference therein any of the provisions of a master form instrument recorded as provided in this section shall have like effect as if such provisions of the master form so incorporated by reference had been set forth fully in the mortgage.

History.

Laws 1967, ch. 226, § 3; W.S. 1957, § 34-48.3.

§ 34-2-112. Master form mortgage; matters not recorded.

Whenever a mortgage is presented for recording on which is set forth matter purporting to be a copy or reproduction of such master form instrument or of part thereof, identified by its title as provided in W.S. 34-2-109 and stating the date when it was recorded and the book and page where it was recorded, preceded by the words “do not record” or “not to be recorded”, and on a separate page from the matter to be recorded as a part of the mortgage in such manner that it will not appear upon a photographic reproduction of any page containing any part of the mortgage, such matter shall not be recorded by the recorder to whom the instrument is presented for recording; in such case the recorder shall record only the mortgage apart from such matter and shall not be liable for so doing, any other provisions of law to the contrary notwithstanding.

History.

Laws 1967, ch. 226, § 4; W.S. 1957, § 34-48.4.

Dates. —

Because the “Deed of Trust Contract” failed to state the date of the trust instrument, it did not create a valid trust under Wyoming law. 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 141819.

§ 34-2-113. Cancellation form for mortgage or deed of trust; recordation; effect.

  1. A cancellation or discharge of mortgage or deed of trust may be in the following form substantially:
  2. Such cancellation or discharge shall be entered in a book kept for that purpose, and signed by the mortgagee or trustee, his attorney-in-fact, executor, administrator or assigns, in the presence of the county clerk or his deputy who shall subscribe the same as a witness, and such cancellation or discharge shall have the same effect as a deed or release duly acknowledged and recorded.

Certificate of Discharge This certifies that a (mortgage or deed of trust, as the case may be) from to dated A.D. and recorded in book of on page has been fully satisfied by the payment of the debt secured thereby, and is hereby cancelled and discharged. Signed in the presence of county clerk of County. Filed and recorded A.D. at M. County clerk

Click to view

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 93, § 4; R.S. 1899, § 2777; C.S. 1910, § 3669; C.S. 1920, § 4626; R.S. 1931, § 71-204; C.S. 1945, § 66-208; W.S. 1957, § 34-49.

Quitclaim deed not release of mortgage. —

Quitclaim deed from mortgagee to assignee of mortgagor will not operate as release of mortgage if not so intended. Chesney v. Valley Live Stock Co., 34 Wyo. 378, 244 P. 216, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (Wyo. 1926).

Failure to enter cancellation. —

Because a debtor's note was set-off against her obligation to a limited liability company (LLC) as allowed by Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 1-15-417, the note was satisfied and a mortgage terminated at the time the LLC answered a creditor's writ of garnishment. As the debtor did not file her petition until after that date, the mortgage was not property of the estate, regardless of the fact that the LLC did not file a cancellation form or discharge as required under Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 34-2-113 and 34-1-130, and thus, the creditor did not violate the automatic stay by seeking to foreclose on the LLC's property. In re Ford, 2013 Bankr. LEXIS 179 (Bankr. D. Wyo. Jan. 16, 2013).

§ 34-2-114. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2008, ch. 20, § 3.

Editor's notes. —

These sections, which derived from Laws 1965, ch. 72, §§ 1 through 5, Laws 1879, ch. 22, § 1, and Laws 1897, ch. 23, § 1, related to certificates of acknowledgement.

§ 34-2-115. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2008, ch. 20, § 3.

§ 34-2-116. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2008, ch. 20, § 3.

§ 34-2-117. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2008, ch. 20, § 3.

§ 34-2-118. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2008, ch. 20, § 3.

Repealing clauses. —

Section 6, ch. 72, Laws 1965, repealed all laws and parts of laws in conflict with that act.

Editor's notes. —

Laws 1965, ch. 72, § 7 makes the act effective on January 1, 1966.

§ 34-2-119. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2008, ch. 20, § 3.

Cross references. —

For other provisions as to who may take acknowledgments and as to manner of taking, see §§ 34-1-113 to 34-1-115.

§ 34-2-120. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2008, ch. 20, § 3.

Cross references. —

As to officers authorized to administer oaths generally, see § 1-2-102.

§ 34-2-121. Conveyance and encumbrance of homesteads void unless spouse joins; exception.

Every owner or occupant of a homestead as established herein may voluntarily sell, mortgage, or otherwise dispose of or encumber the same; provided the instrument of writing conveying, mortgaging, disposing of or encumbering such homestead shall contain in substance the following words: “Hereby releasing and waiving all rights under and by virtue of the homestead exemption laws of this state”, and shall be freely and voluntarily signed and acknowledged by the owner and the spouse of the owner of said homestead. The foregoing provisions shall not be applicable to nor shall compliance therewith be required for full legal effectiveness of any conveyance of property directly from husband to wife.

History.

Laws 1886, ch. 60, § 436; R.S. 1887, § 2784; R.S. 1899, § 2770; C.S. 1910, § 3662; Laws 1913, ch. 18, § 1; 1919, ch. 97, § 1; C.S. 1920, § 4619; R.S. 1931, § 97-205; Laws 1941, ch. 42, § 1; C.S. 1945, § 66-209; Laws 1949, ch. 72, § 2; W.S. 1957, § 34-53.

Cross references. —

As to homestead exemption generally, see § 1-20-101 et seq.

History of section. —

Section 5, ch. 62, C.L. 1876, was similar to this section, in its original form, and was amended by § 2, ch. 83, Laws 1886. This section was originally enacted as part of the civil code, ch. 60, Laws 1886. For the remaining portions of the civil code relating to homesteads, see §§ 1-20-101 to 1-20-104.

Section 5 (last paragraph) of ch. 93, Laws 1895, was similar to the above. It read: “No deed or other instrument shall be construed as releasing the right of homestead, unless the same shall contain a clause expressly releasing or waiving such right. And in such case the certificate of acknowledgment shall contain a clause as follows, ‘including the release and waiver of the right of homestead,’ or other words which will expressly show that the parties executing the deed or other instrument intended to release such right. And no release or waiver of the right of homestead by the husband shall bind the wife unless she join in such release or waiver.”

Repeal of provision concerning waiver of homestead. —

Section 66-207, W.C.S. 1945, concerning the right of a grantor to waive homestead exemption, was repealed by § 1, ch. 72, Laws 1949.

Waiver requirements include all homestead property, and are not limited to real property. Geist v. Converse County Bank, 79 B.R. 939, 1987 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 10402 (D. Wyo. 1987).

In Wyoming the homestead can only be sold or incumbered with the consent of the wife, she being required to join in the mortgage or deed; and the right of homestead is to the extent of $1,500, the proceeds upon the sale thereof being exempt from execution or attachment, as well as the homestead itself. From this statement may be inferred the right of exemption of proceeds from sales made other than by execution. United States v. Field, 190 F. Supp. 216, 1960 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 3168 (D. Wyo. 1960).

But conveyance without consent is not void as to amount over $4,000.00. —

A deed by the owner without the consent of his or her spouse, conveying property embracing a homestead, but of a value in excess of $4,000.00, is not void as to the excess. Stolldorf v. Stolldorf, 384 P.2d 969, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 109 (Wyo. 1963).

Proceeds arising from sale of a homestead not exceeding the statutory allowance are exempt. —

No judgment or other claim against the owner of the homestead is a lien against the same in the hands of a bona fide purchaser for a valuable consideration, and the proceeds arising from the sale of a homestead not exceeding the statutory allowance are exempt, and any subsequent homestead acquired by such proceeds is also exempt. United States v. Field, 190 F. Supp. 216, 1960 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 3168 (D. Wyo. 1960).

Clause required to convey homestead interest. —

Since enactment of ch. 19, Laws 1895, to make valid conveyance of homestead or to release homestead interest, it has been necessary that body of instrument and certificate of acknowledgment contain clause expressly releasing or waiving homestead right. Jones v. Losekamp, 19 Wyo. 83, 114 P. 673, 1911 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1911) (construing § 66-207, W.C.S. 1945).

Acknowledgment necessary to pass homestead right. —

A mortgage in which the acknowledgment is not taken as required is ineffectual to pass homestead right. First Nat'l Bank v. Citizens' State Bank, 11 Wyo. 32, 70 P. 726, 1902 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 1902) (construing § 66-207, W.C.S. 1945).

Homestead right not extinguished by death of wife. —

One who has acquired a homestead does not lose his right to exemption by the death of his wife, childless, if he continues to occupy the premises as a home. Towne v. Rumsey, 5 Wyo. 11, 35 P. 1025, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1894).

Partnership funds used to purchase homestead. —

Where the other partner consents, a homestead may be purchased with partnership funds for a partner and his wife. State Bank v. Bagley Bros., 44 Wyo. 244, 11 P.2d 572, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 44 Wyo. 456, 13 P.2d 564, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 33 (Wyo. 1932).

And wife's signature necessary to mortgage for partnership debt. —

Property purchased with partnership funds was in fact the homestead of a deceased partner and mortgage thereon to secure partnership debts was void as to the partner's wife, who did not sign the mortgage. State Bank v. Bagley Bros., 44 Wyo. 244, 11 P.2d 572, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 44 Wyo. 456, 13 P.2d 564, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 33 (Wyo. 1932).

Mortgage securing purchase price is superior to homestead right. —

A mortgage by a grantee to a third person for money loaned to pay the purchase price of homestead, as well as a purchase money mortgage to the grantor, is excepted from homestead exemption laws. Powers v. Pense, 20 Wyo. 327, 123 P. 925, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 1912) (construing § 66-207, W.C.S. 1945).

And purchaser at foreclosure sale gets superior rights. —

Rights of purchaser at mortgage foreclosure sale held superior to the homestead exemption rights of the wife where the money had been advanced in order that the property might be redeemed from a purchase money foreclosure. Powers v. Pense, 20 Wyo. 327, 123 P. 925, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 1912) (construing § 66-207, W.C.S. 1945).

Where the mortgage lien is superior to the homestead right, the lien of the purchaser at foreclosure sale is also superior. Powers v. Pense, 20 Wyo. 327, 123 P. 925, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 1912) (construing § 66-207, W.C.S. 1945).

Absent waiver, no attachment of nonpurchase-money lien. —

A consensual, but nonpurchase-money, lien does not attach to the first $10,000 in value of a debtor's homestead unless it is accompanied by an informed, voluntary and specific waiver of the homestead exemption. In re VanGorp, 128 B.R. 579, 1991 Bankr. LEXIS 881 (Bankr. D. Wyo. 1991).

Homestead exemption denied. —

One who did not reside on the land, nor occupy it as his homestead, and made no claim of homestead exemption until long after execution of a deed thereto, could not claim exemption as against the grantees. Harney v. Montgomery, 29 Wyo. 362, 213 P. 378, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1923).

Occupant of homestead as proper defendant in ejectment action. —

Widow who occupied mortgaged premises, claiming them as homestead in her individual, not representative, capacity was a proper party defendant in an ejectment action. Delfelder v. Teton Land & Inv. Co., 46 Wyo. 142, 24 P.2d 702, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 46 Wyo. 142, 26 P.2d 153, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 1933).

Effect of former provision requiring officer to apprise wife of her rights. —

Before the 1949 amendment this section required the officer taking a wife's acknowledgment of a conveyance or encumbrance of homestead to apprise her of her right and the effect of signing and acknowledging the instrument. This provision was held not to apply to a widow, since it was intended to protect a wife against undue influence on the part of her husband. Goodson v. Smith, 69 Wyo. 439, 243 P.2d 163, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1952).

Notary was not required to advise wife concerning her rights and effect of signing and acknowledging deed, where wife failed to examine instrument, saying she knew all about the matter, and where husband advised notary wife was sick and that notary should not stay longer than necessary. Rowray v. Atlas Realty Co., 48 Wyo. 264, 45 P.2d 18, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 36 (Wyo. 1935).

Quoted in

Burnell v. Roush, 404 P.2d 836, 1965 Wyo. LEXIS 148 (Wyo. 1965); Gregory v. Sanders, 635 P.2d 795, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 384 (Wyo. 1981).

Cited in

Adams v. Smith, 11 Wyo. 200, 70 P. 1043, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (1903); Whalon v. North Platte Canal & Colonization Co., 11 Wyo. 313, 71 P. 995, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (1903); Ohio Oil Co. v. Wyoming Agency, 63 Wyo. 187, 179 P.2d 773, 1947 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (1947); Strom v. Felton, 76 Wyo. 370, 302 P.2d 917, 1956 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (1956).

Law reviews. —

See note, “The Spouse as a Stranger to the Deed,” 14 Wyo. L.J. 61 (1959).

See note, “Should Marital Rights Be Protected by Statute?,” 19 Wyo. L.J. 14 (1964).

See article, “Wyoming's Law of Decedents' Estates, Guardianship and Trusts: A Comparison with the Uniform Probate Code — Part I,” VII Land & Water L. Rev. 169 (1972).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Recovery of damages for breach of contract to convey homestead where only one spouse signed contract, 5 ALR4th 1310.

Library References. —

American Law of Mining, 2nd Edition § 131.03 (Matthew Bender).

§ 34-2-122. Notice of trust or representative capacity of grantee.

In all instruments conveying real estate, or interests therein, in which the grantee is described as trustee, agent, or as in any other representative capacity, the instruments of conveyance shall also define the trust or other agreement under which the grantee is acting. In all instruments conveying real estate, or interests therein, in which the grantee is described as a trust, the instrument of conveyance shall also define the trust or other instrument and shall be deemed to have vested title in the trustee or trustees of the trust. For purposes of this section, it shall be sufficient to define a trust by providing in the text of the instrument the name of the trustee or trustees and the name of the trust, the date of the trust or other agreement, or by referring by proper description of the affecting record book, page, document number or file, to the instrument, order, decree or other writing, which is of public record in the county in which the land so conveyed is located and in which the required information appears; otherwise the description of a grantee in any representative capacity in each instrument of conveyance shall be considered and held to be a description of the grantee, only, and shall not be notice of any trust, agency or other representative capacity of the grantee who shall be held as vested with the power to convey, transfer, encumber or release the affected title. Whenever the grantee shall execute and deliver a conveyance, transfer, encumbrance or release of the property in a representative capacity, it shall not thereafter be questioned by anyone claiming as a beneficiary under the trust or agency or by anyone claiming by, through or under any undisclosed beneficiary. Trust property in the name of the trustee, agent or representative and owned only in that capacity shall not be subject to execution for the grantee’s individual obligations.

History.

Laws 1947, ch. 154, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 34-54; Laws 1992, ch. 16, § 1.

Naming of beneficiaries. —

Where the warranty deed conveyed property from husband and wife to their revocable trust that was executed the same day, the deed complied with the plain requirement of the statute because the statute requires the deed to name the beneficiaries only when the grantee is a trustee or other individual agent. In re Estate of Lohrie, 950 P.2d 1030, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 154 (Wyo. 1997).

Dates. —

Because the “Deed of Trust Contract” failed to state the date of the trust instrument, it did not create a valid trust under Wyoming law. 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 141819.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity and construction of trust instrument which fails to designate respective interests of beneficiaries, 87 ALR3d 925.

§ 34-2-123. Notice of trust or representative capacity of grantee; prior conveyances.

Any instrument which complies with this act [§§ 34-2-122 and 34-2-123] shall be effective regardless of when it was executed or recorded. All instruments of conveyance to, or transfer, encumbrance or release of, lands or any interest therein within the state of Wyoming, which name a grantee in a representative capacity, or name a trust as grantee, and which fail to provide the information required by W.S. 34-2-122, shall cease to be notice of any trust or representative capacity of the grantee and shall be considered and held to be a description of the grantee only, who shall be held to have individually, the full power to convey, transfer, encumber or release the affected title and no conveyance, transfer, encumbrance or release shall thereafter be questioned by anyone claiming with respect to the affected property, as a beneficiary or by anyone claiming by, through, or under an undisclosed beneficiary, provided that this section shall not apply if the grantee or any beneficiary or beneficiaries or other properly interested person shall file for record in the proper office of the county in which the land is situated, a statement, duly verified, describing the affected lands and interest therein, setting forth the interest of the person or entity making the statement, defining the representative relationship, and setting forth the information required by W.S. 34-2-122, or referring by proper description to an instrument of public record in the county in which the matters shall appear. The identity of any successor trustee may be established by a recorded statement, duly verified, of the successor trustee specifying his name and address and the date and circumstances of his succession, and confirming that he is currently lawfully serving in that capacity.

History.

Laws 1947, ch. 154, § 2; W.S. 1957, § 34-55; Laws 1992, ch. 16, § 1.

Naming of beneficiaries. —

Where the warranty deed conveyed property from husband and wife to their revocable trust that was executed the same day, the deed complied with the plain requirement of the statute because the statute requires the deed to name the beneficiaries only when the grantee is a trustee or other individual agent. In re Estate of Lohrie, 950 P.2d 1030, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 154 (Wyo. 1997).

§ 34-2-124. Priority of mortgages or specific liens on realty.

A mortgage or other specific lien on real property shall take precedence over the lien of taxes levied against any other property than the property subject to such lien.

History.

Laws 1919, ch. 94, § 1; C.S. 1920, § 4655; R.S. 1931, § 71-227; C.S. 1945, § 66-210; W.S. 1957, § 34-56.

Cross references. —

For provision that materialmen's liens may be enforced by removal of improvements, see § 29-2-103.

As to priority of lien in connection with mines and minerals to prior perfected lien, see § 29-3-107.

As to priority of lien of harvesters with reference to mortgages, etc., see § 29-5-104.

As to liens on real estate for taxes, see § 39-13-108.

Effect of section. —

Section 2, ch. 94, Laws 1919, provides that the act shall be deemed declaratory of the existing law.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Priority between vendor's lien and mortgage or deed of trust to third person furnishing purchase money, 55 ALR2d 1119.

Priority between mechanics' lien and purchase-money mortgage, 73 ALR2d 1407.

Special or local assessment as superior over earlier private lien or mortgage, where statute creating such special lien is silent as to superiority, 75 ALR2d 1121.

Priority between advances made under previously executed mortgage and mechanics' lien, 80 ALR2d 179.

Priority between federal tax lien and mortgage to secure future advances or expenditures by mortgagee, 90 ALR2d 1179.

Right of vendee under executory land contract to lien for amount paid on purchase price as against subsequent creditors of purchasers from vendor, 82 ALR3d 1040.

§ 34-2-125. Private seals.

Hereafter it shall not be necessary to use private seals on any instrument in this state.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 93, § 5 1/2; C.S. 1945, § 66-214; W.S. 1957, § 34-57.

History of section. —

This section seems not to have been carried in any compilation prior to 1945.

Earlier compilations carried § 1, ch. 71, Laws 1890 (R.S. 1931, § 97-122), which read: “The use of private seals in written contracts except those of corporations, is abolished, and the addition of a private seal to an instrument of writing shall not affect its character in any respect.”

The 1895 act was substituted by the 1945 compiler on the ground that it was later in point of time.

Presence of private seal. —

Under this section and §§ 34-2-126 and 34-2-127, presence of an unnecessary private seal on writing does not entitle its recitals to any effect that they would not have had without it. Natrona Power Co. v. Clark, 31 Wyo. 284, 225 P. 586, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (Wyo. 1924).

§ 34-2-126. Unsealed writings.

There shall be no difference in evidence between sealed and unsealed writings and every writing not sealed shall have the same force and effect that it would have if sealed. A writing under seal may, therefore, be changed or altogether discharged by a writing not under seal. An agreement in writing without seal for the compromise or settlement of a debt is as obligatory as if the seal were affixed.

History.

Laws 1890, ch. 71, § 2; R.S. 1899, § 2750; C.S. 1910, § 3642; C.S. 1920, § 4598; R.S. 1931, § 97-123; C.S. 1945, § 66-215; W.S. 1957, § 34-58.

Cited in

State ex rel. Nash v. Cowhick, 9 Wyo. 93, 60 P. 265, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (1900); Natrona Power Co. v. Clark, 31 Wyo. 284, 225 P. 586, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (1924); Carey v. Jackson, 603 P.2d 868, 1979 Wyo. LEXIS 493 (Wyo. 1979).

§ 34-2-127. Recitals in instruments.

Recitals in any written instrument shall have no greater effect than they have heretofore had in writings not under seal.

History.

Laws 1890, ch. 71, § 3; R.S. 1899, § 2751; C.S. 1910, § 3643; C.S. 1920, § 4599; R.S. 1931, § 97-124; C.S. 1945, § 66-216; W.S. 1957, § 34-59.

Cited in

Natrona Power Co. v. Clark, 31 Wyo. 284, 225 P. 586, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (1924).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Written matter as controlling printed matter in resolving inconsistencies between habendum and other clauses, 37 ALR2d 820.

Intent of parties as determining effect of conflict between granting and habendum clauses as to estate conveyed, 58 ALR2d 1374.

Conflict between granting and habendum clauses as to estate conveyed, 58 ALR2d 1374.

Deed to railroad company as conveying fee or easement, 6 ALR3d 973.

Rights, under oil and gas lease, deed or sales contract, to “distillate,” “condensate,” or “natural gasoline,” 38 ALR3d 983.

Description in deed as relating to magnetic or true meridian, 70 ALR3d 1220.

§ 34-2-128. No implied tenancy except by sufferance.

In this state there shall not exist the relations of landlord and tenant, by implication or operation of law, except a tenancy by sufferance. Upon the expiration of a term created by lease, either verbal or written, there shall be no implied renewal of the same, for any period of time whatever, either by the tenant holding over or by the landlord accepting compensation or rent for or during any period of such holding over. Such holding over by the tenant and acceptance of rent by the landlord shall constitute only a tenancy by sufferance, with the rights, duties, obligations and incidents of such tenancy.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 72, § 1; R.S. 1887, § 1386; R.S. 1899, § 2772; C.S. 1910, § 3664; C.S. 1920, § 4621; R.S. 1931, § 97-207; C.S. 1945, § 66-219; W.S. 1957, § 34-60.

Tenancy after lease expires is tenancy by sufferance. —

District court did not err in granting summary judgment in favor of defendant on plaintiff's claim that defendant deprived him of a constitutionally-protected property right by excluding him from a medical office suite, because defendant was a tenant by sufferance after the lease expired and had no property rights. Brecheen v. Lofaro, 559 Fed. Appx. 723, 2014 U.S. App. LEXIS 9416 (10th Cir. Wyo. 2014).

Possession indicates tenancy by sufferance. —

One in possession of property is, in absence of any other showing, a mere tenant by sufferance, so that such possession cannot be regarded as imparting vitality to a lease the conditions of which have not been complied with, nor as a part performance of a contract for the occupancy of land. Frank v. Stratford-Handcock, 13 Wyo. 37, 77 P. 134, 1904 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1904).

Tenancy after lease expires is tenancy by sufferance. —

Under this section and § 34-2-129, tenant's occupancy of premises after expiration of lease, without any new understanding, continued as “tenant by sufferance.” Lawer v. Mitts, 33 Wyo. 249, 238 P. 654, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 1925).

Tenant after expiration of written lease is only tenant by sufferance. Hitshew v. Rosson, 41 Wyo. 509, 287 P. 316, 1930 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (Wyo. 1930).

And notice to quit unnecessary. —

Where oral lease expired Sept. 1, 1942, but tenants remained in apartment under oral agreement, at increased rent while looking for other apartment, only tenancy by sufferance remained and notice to quit was unnecessary. Welch v. Rice, 61 Wyo. 511, 159 P.2d 502, 1945 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 1945).

Right of peaceable reentry. —

Where landlord gave notice to tenants by sufferance to quit apartment, tenants became trespassers at expiration of period set and landlord was entitled to enter apartment peaceably and remove such trespasser's property therefrom. Welch v. Rice, 61 Wyo. 511, 159 P.2d 502, 1945 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 1945).

Termination by reentry. —

Tenancy by sufferance can be terminated by reentry or any affirmative action on landlord's part which indicates he desires tenant to surrender premises and notice to quit is not necessary unless required by statute. Welch v. Rice, 61 Wyo. 511, 159 P.2d 502, 1945 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 1945).

Or by action in forcible entry and unlawful detainer. —

Administrator of deceased landlord, after serving on tenant by sufferance notice to quit in due time and sufficient in form and substance, may recover possession in forcible entry and unlawful detainer. Hitshew v. Rosson, 41 Wyo. 509, 287 P. 316, 1930 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (Wyo. 1930).

Cited in

Goddard v. State, 481 P.2d 343, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 199 (Wyo. 1971).

Law reviews. —

See comment, “Application of Wyoming Statutes: Section 34-60 [§ 34-2-128] (1957) — The Possibility of Implied Tenancies Other Than Tenancies by Sufferance in Wyoming,” VI Land & Water L. Rev. 553 (1971).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Farmland cultivation arrangement as creating status of landlord-tenant or landowner-cropper, 95 ALR3d 1013.

Waiver or estoppel as to notice requirement for exercising option to renew or extend lease, 32 ALR4th 452.

Lessor's retention of past-due rental payments as precluding termination of lease and dispossession of lessee for nonpayment of rent, 39 ALR4th 1204.

What constitutes abandonment of residential or commercial lease — modern cases, 84 ALR4th 183.

What constitutes tenant's holding over of leased premises, 13 ALR5th 169.

Landlord's permitting third party to occupy premises rent-free as acceptance of tenant's surrender of premises, 18 ALR5th 437.

§ 34-2-129. Leases; renewal.

No lease which shall have expired by its own limitation shall be again renewed except by express contract in writing, signed by the parties thereto, whether the original lease be written or verbal. Nor shall any other tenancy than that by sufferance exist after the termination of the original lease, unless created as aforesaid, by express contract in writing.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 72, § 2; R.S. 1887, § 1387; R.S. 1899, § 2773; C.S. 1910, § 3665; C.S. 1920, § 4622; R.S. 1931, § 97-208; C.S. 1945, § 66-220; W.S. 1957, § 34-61.

Renewals must be in writing and signed. —

Where a lease on medical office space expired according to its terms, handwritten notations were insufficient to successfully modify terms of lease agreement. The lease provisions were consistent with Wyoming law which required lease renewals to be in writing and signed by the parties. Brecheen v. Lofaro, 559 Fed. Appx. 723, 2014 U.S. App. LEXIS 9416 (10th Cir. Wyo. 2014).

No implied renewal of lease. —

Upon expiration of term created by lease, either verbal or written, there can be no implied renewal under the statute for any period of time whatever, and a judgment for rent after expiration of term was erroneous. McNamara v. O'Brien, 2 Wyo. 447, 1881 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1881).

Notice to quit unnecessary. —

Where oral lease expired Sept. 1, 1942, but tenants remained in apartment under oral agreement, at increased rent while looking for other apartment, only tenancy by sufferance remained and notice to quit was unnecessary. Welch v. Rice, 61 Wyo. 511, 159 P.2d 502, 1945 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 1945).

Right of peaceable reentry. —

Where landlord gave notice to tenants by sufferance to quit apartment, tenants became trespassers at expiration of period set and landlord was entitled to enter apartment peaceably and remove such trespasser's property therefrom. Welch v. Rice, 61 Wyo. 511, 159 P.2d 502, 1945 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 1945).

Exercise of right of reentry not conversion of tenant's personal property. —

A tenant holding over after the expiration of his lease became a tenant by sufferance under this section and § 34-2-128, and the landlord had the right of peaceful reentry, and the landlord was not guilty of conversion of the tenant's personal property on the premises in exercising such right, or in removing the property to a warehouse subject to the tenant's order. Vissenberg v. Bresnahen, 65 Wyo. 367, 202 P.2d 663, 1949 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 1949).

Tenancy terminated by reentry. —

Tenancy by sufferance can be terminated by reentry or any affirmative action on landlord's part which indicates he desires tenant to surrender premises and notice to quit is not necessary unless required by statute. Welch v. Rice, 61 Wyo. 511, 159 P.2d 502, 1945 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 1945).

Cited in

Lawer v. Mitts, 33 Wyo. 249, 238 P. 654, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (1925); Hitshew v. Rosson, 41 Wyo. 509, 287 P. 316, 1930 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (1930).

Law reviews. —

See comment, “Application of Wyoming Statutes: Section 34-60 [§ 34-2-128] (1957) — The Possibility of Implied Tenancies Other Than Tenancies by Sufferance in Wyoming,” VI Land & Water L. Rev. 553 (1971).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Assignee's right to enforce lessor's covenant to renew or extend lease, 29 ALR2d 837.

Inclusion or exclusion of first and last days in computing time for giving notice of termination of lease which must be given a certain number of days before a known future date, 98 ALR2d 1331.

Validity and enforceability of provision for renewal of lease at rental to be fixed by subsequent agreement of the parties, 58 ALR3d 500.

Lessee's first privilege option to purchase or terms of similar import as requiring existence of prior offer from third party, 76 ALR3d 1139.

Requirements as to certainty and completeness of terms of lease in agreement to lease, 85 ALR3d 414.

Inability to obtain license, permit, or charter required for tenant's business as defense to enforcement of lease, 89 ALR3d 329.

Application of statutory landlord's lien to property of third person used by tenant on rented premises, 95 ALR3d 1205.

Life tenant's death as affecting rights under lease given by him, 14 ALR4th 1054.

Failure or delay in giving notice within specified time of intention to renew lease, 27 ALR4th 266, 29 ALR4th 903, 29 ALR4th 956, 32 ALR4th 452, 34 ALR4th 857.

Sufficiency of notice of exercise of option of renewal in lease, 27 ALR4th 266, 29 ALR4th 903, 29 ALR4th 956, 32 ALR4th 452, 34 ALR4th 857.

Second or perpetual renewal under provision for renewal of lease, 29 ALR4th 172.

Sufficiency of provision of lease to effect second or perpetual right of renewal, 29 ALR4th 172.

Sufficiency as to method of giving oral or written notice exercising option to renew or extend lease, 29 ALR4th 903.

What constitutes timely notice of exercise of option to renew or extend lease, 29 ALR4th 956.

Waiver or estoppel as to notice requirement for exercising option to renew or extend lease, 32 ALR4th 452.

Sufficiency as to parties giving or receiving notice of exercise of option to renew or extend lease, 34 ALR4th 857.

Sublessee's rights with respect to primary lessee's option to renew lease, 39 ALR4th 824.

Respective rights in excess rent when landlord relets at higher rent during lessee's term, 50 ALR4th 403.

Commercial leases: application of rule that lease may be canceled only for “material” breach, 54 ALR4th 595.

What constitutes tenant's holding over of leased premises, 13 ALR5th 169.

§ 34-2-130. Leases; expiration of oil, gas or other mineral leases; failure to record cancellation or other termination.

If any lessee, his personal representative, successor or assign, as the case may be, after an oil, gas or other mineral lease has expired, been cancelled, surrendered, relinquished or otherwise terminated shall for the space of twenty (20) days after being thereto requested, fail, refuse or neglect to record in the office of the county clerk of the county wherein the lands described in said lease are located a recordable certificate or deed of discharge or release thereof, he shall be liable to the lessor, his heirs or assigns for all damages occasioned by such failure, refusal, or neglect, to be recovered in a civil action. The lessor’s request for discharge or release shall be in writing and delivered to the lessee by personal service or registered mail at his last known address. A letterpress or carbon or written copy of said demand, when shown to be such, may be used as evidence in any court with the same force and effect as the original.

History.

Laws 1957, ch. 24, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 34-62; Laws 2009, ch. 168, § 206.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, deleted “and ex officio register of deeds” following “county clerk” in the first sentence.

Law reviews. —

See article, “Forfeiture and Termination of Mining Leases,” I Land & Water L. Rev. 201 (1966).

§ 34-2-131. Tax deeds; definitions.

  1. As used in this act [§§ 34-2-131 through 34-2-135]:
    1. “Tax deed” means any conveyance executed by or on behalf of the state, or any county, municipality, or other taxing or assessment unit thereof, which conveys or purports to convey real estate pursuant to any sale, foreclosure, forfeiture or other proceeding to satisfy the lien or indebtedness of any tax or special assessment;
    2. “Former owner” means any person whose interest or estate has been conveyed or purportedly conveyed, or extinguished or purportedly extinguished, by execution of any tax deed, and any other persons claiming by, through or under him;
    3. “Grantee” means the grantee named in any tax deed, and any other persons claiming by, through or under him;
    4. “Possession” refers to possession, and to the extent of possession, as determined by the rules applicable in determining the existence of adverse possession under a written instrument constituting color of title, and includes possession by tenant or agent.

History.

Laws 1975, ch. 170, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 34-62.1.

Cross references. —

As to deed for property sold for taxes and purchased by county, see §§ 39-13-107, 39-13-108.

As to tax deeds in connection with real estate sold for taxes, see §§ 39-13-108, 39-13-109.

As to deed when property sold by sheriff to enforce lien acquired by purchase at tax sales, see § 39-13-108.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

“Possession definition inapplicable to quiet title action.” —

The definition of “possession” found in subsection (a)(iv) of this section pertains only to §§ 34-2-131 through 34-2-135 and cannot be applied to a determination of whether a party has complied with the possession requirement under § 1-32-201 (action to quiet title). Goodrich v. Stobbe, 908 P.2d 416, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 226 (Wyo. 1995).

Law reviews. —

See comment, “Marketable Title Legislation: Tax Deeds in Wyoming,” XI Land & Water L. Rev. 419 (1976).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Statutory limitation of period for attack on tax deed as affected by failure to comply with statutory requirement as to notice before tax deed, 5 ALR2d 1021.

Void tax deed, tax sale certificate and the like as constituting color of title, 38 ALR2d 986.

§ 34-2-132. Tax deeds; 2-year limitation.

  1. No action, suit or other proceeding shall be commenced by the former owner to set aside, declare invalid or redeem from a tax deed or the sale, forfeiture, foreclosure or other proceeding upon which it is based or to recover possession, quiet title or otherwise litigate or contest the title of the grantee, if:
    1. Two (2) years or more have elapsed after the date of recording the deed in the office of the county clerk for the county in which the real estate described in the deed is situated; and
    2. The grantee has been in possession of the real estate continuously for a period of at least six (6) months, at any time after one (1) year and six (6) months have elapsed since the date of recording of the tax deed.
  2. The limitation in subsection (a) of this section applies regardless of whether the tax deed or any of the proceedings upon which it is based are void or voidable for any reason, jurisdictional or otherwise. If the deed is executed substantially in the form prescribed for the execution of tax deeds, the limitation shall apply regardless of whether the deed is deemed void upon its face. The period shall not be extended by reason of the minority, insanity, imprisonment, nonresidence, or death of any person, or by reason of any other fact, or circumstance.

History.

Laws 1975, ch. 170, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 34-62.2; Laws 2009, ch. 168, § 206.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, deleted “and ex officio register of deeds” following “county clerk” in (a)(i).

Meaning of “in possession.” —

For purposes of being in possession under subsection (a)(ii), the words “in possession” mean an actual physical entry on the land; further, physical entry must be followed by the doing of acts of dominion on the land of such kind and in such manner as to indicate plainly that the entrant is acting as the owner thereof would act, considering the character of the land and the purposes for which it is adapted, the size and location of the land, and all of the attendant circumstances. Trefren v. Lewis, 852 P.2d 323, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 94 (Wyo. 1993).

No possession. —

Because tax deed owners did not take possession of their lots, they could not take advantage of the provisions by which the Wyoming Legislature offered protection to their tax deeds, including this section. White v. Woods, 2009 WY 29, 2009 WY 29A, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 47 (Wyo. 2009).

Cited in

Goodrich v. Stobbe, 908 P.2d 416, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 226 (Wyo. 1995).

§ 34-2-133. Tax deeds; possession and affidavits of possession.

  1. Possession by the grantee for a continuous period of not less than six (6) months at any time after one (1) year and six (6) months have elapsed since the date of recording the tax deed extinguishes forever all the claims, right, title and interest, including the right to possession, of the former owner, and vests in the grantee any title conveyed or purportedly conveyed by the tax deed. Proof of possession by the grantee and the record of the tax deed constitutes conclusive evidence of the legality and effectiveness of the deed and any proceedings upon which the deed is based, and of the title of the grantee. As a means of proving possession and preserving evidence of possession under a tax deed, the then owner or holder of the title conveyed or purportedly conveyed by the tax deed may, at any time after two (2) years from the date of recording of the tax deed, file for record in the office of the county clerk in which the real estate is located an affidavit substantially in the following form:
  2. In any action, suit or proceeding in which the tax deed, any proceedings upon which it is based, or the title of the grantee is contested or drawn in question, a certified copy of the record of any affidavit of possession and claim under tax deed which has been of record for not less than sixty (60) days constitutes prima facie evidence of the facts recited therein and of the application of this act [§§ 34-2-131 through 34-2-135].

AFFIDAVIT OF POSSESSION AND CLAIM UNDER TAX DEED State of County ss I, , (name) residing at (address), being first duly sworn, depose and say that on (date) a tax deed was issued to (grantee) for the following described real estate: that said tax deed was filed for record in the office of the county clerk for county, , on (date), and appears in the records of that office in County as recorded in book page of the records; that I am now in possession of such real estate and claim title to the same by virtue of such tax deed; that I have been in possession of such real estate for a continuous period of not less than six (6) months immediately preceding the date of this affidavit; and that the facts concerning the possession of such real estate from the date of recording the tax deed to the date of this notice are, insofar as known to me, as follows: Subscribed and sworn to before me this day of , (year). Notarial Officer in and for County (state)

Click to view

History.

Laws 1975, ch. 170, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 34-62.3; Laws 1999, ch. 150, § 2; 2009, ch. 168, § 206; 2011, ch. 113, § 2.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in the last sentence before the form, deleted “and ex officio register of deeds” following “county clerk” in (a).

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in the form in (a), deleted “and ex officio register of deeds” following “county clerk,” and substituted “Notarial Officer” for “Notary Public.”

§ 34-2-134. Tax deeds; liberal construction; legislative purposes.

This act [§§ 34-2-131 through 34-2-135] shall be liberally construed to effectuate the legislative purpose of giving stability and effect to record titles, of confirming and clarifying the titles of persons in possession, of providing a means of correcting procedural and jurisdictional defects without necessity of resort to further proceedings, and of rendering tax titles marketable and protecting purchasers thereof against remote claims.

History.

Laws 1975, ch. 170, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 34-62.4.

§ 34-2-135. Tax deeds; provisions cumulative and retroactive; effective date.

Nothing in this act [§§ 34-2-131 through 34-2-135] shall be construed to extend the period of any other applicable statute of limitations or to permit the commencement of any proceeding or the enforcement of any claim or interest which is barred by lapse of time or for any other reason. This act shall apply to tax deeds heretofore or hereafter recorded, but the commencement of any action, suit or proceeding shall not be precluded by this act until two (2) years after its effective date. No affidavit shall be recorded pursuant to this act until two (2) years after its effective date. This act shall not apply to tax deeds issued only covering severed oil, gas, hydrocarbons and other minerals and estates therein.

History.

Laws 1975, ch. 170, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 34-62.5.

Editor's notes. —

Section 2, ch. 170, Laws 1975, makes the act effective 90 days after adjournment. The session adjourned on March 1, 1975.

§ 34-2-136. Form of special warranty deed.

Conveyances of land may be substantially in the following form:

Special Warranty Deed A. B., grantor, (here insert name or names and place of residence), for and in consideration of (here insert consideration) in hand paid, conveys and specially warrants against all who claim by, through, or under the grantor, but against none other, to C. D., grantee, (here insert grantee’s name or names and place of residence) the following described real estate (here insert description) situate in the county of , state of Wyoming. Dated this day of A.D. A.B.

Click to view

History.

Laws 2015, ch. 106, § 1.

Effective date. — Laws 2015, ch. 106, § 2, makes the act effective July 1, 2015.

§ 34-2-137 Form of special warranty deed; effect.

  1. Every deed in substance in the form prescribed in W.S. 34-2-136, when otherwise duly executed, shall have the effect of:
    1. A conveyance in fee simple to the grantee, the grantee’s heirs, and assigns, of the property named in the special warranty deed, together with all the appurtenances, rights and privileges belonging to the property; and
    2. A covenant from the grantor that:
      1. The granted property is free from all encumbrances made by that grantor; and
      2. The grantor will forever warrant and defend the title of the property in the grantee, the grantee’s heirs and assigns against any lawful claim and demand of the grantor and any person claiming or to claim by, through, or under the grantor, but against none other.
  2. Any exceptions to a covenant described in paragraph (a)(ii) of this section, may be inserted in the deed following the description of the land.

History.

Laws 2015, ch. 106, § 1.

Effective date. — Laws 2015, ch. 106, § 2, makes the act effective July 1, 2015.

§ 34-3-101. Form.

A deed of trust to secure debts or indemnify sureties may be in the following form, or to the same effect:

This deed, made the . . . . . day . . . . . , in the year of . . . . . , between . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . (the grantor) of the one part, and . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . (the trustee) of the other part; witnesseth: That the said . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . (the grantor) doth (or do) grant unto the said . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . (the trustee) the following property (here describe it), in trust to secure (here describe the debts to be secured or the sureties to be indemnified, and insert covenants or any other provisions the parties may agree upon); witness the following signatures and seals (or signature and seal).

History.

Laws 1877, p. 94, § 1; R.S. 1887, § 52; R.S. 1899, § 2796; C.S. 1910, § 3688; C.S. 1920, § 4646; R.S. 1931, § 71-218; C.S. 1945, § 59-301; W.S. 1957, § 34-63.

Cross references. —

As to form of real estate mortgage, see § 34-2-107.

§ 34-3-102. Trustee's sale; generally.

  1. The trustee in any such deed, except so far as may be therein otherwise provided, shall, whenever required by any creditor secured or any surety indemnified by the deed, or the personal representative of any such creditor or surety, after the debt due to such creditor, or for which such surety may be liable, shall have become payable, and default shall have been made in the payment thereof, or any part thereof, by the grantor, sell the property conveyed by the deed, or so much thereof as may be necessary, at public auction, for cash, having first given notice of such sale as hereinafter prescribed, and shall apply the proceeds of sale, first to the payment of expenses attending the execution of the trust, including a commission to the trustee of five percent (5%) on first three hundred dollars ($300.00) and two percent (2%) on the residue of the proceeds, and then, pro rata (or in the order of priority, if any, prescribed by the deed) to the payment of the debts secured and the indemnity of the sureties indemnified by the deed, and shall pay the surplus, if any, to the grantor, his heirs, personal representatives, or assigns. Every such notice of such sale shall show the following particulars:
    1. The time and place of sale;
    2. The names of the parties to the deed under which it will be made;
    3. The date of the deed;
    4. The office and book in which it is recorded;
    5. The quantity and description of the land or other property, or both, conveyed thereby;
    6. The names of the persons secured or indemnified thereby;
    7. The amount secured and the time when payable;
    8. The amount of credits, if any, to which the same is subject;
    9. The amount of the principal and interest claimed to be due and unpaid, and for which the sale will be made.

History.

Laws 1877, p. 95, § 2; R.S. 1887, § 53; R.S. 1899, § 2797; C.S. 1910, § 3689; C.S. 1920, § 4647; R.S. 1931, § 71-219; C.S. 1945, § 59-302; W.S. 1957, § 34-64.

Cross references. —

As to foreclosure of mortgages and power of sale generally, see chapter 4 of this title.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 34-3-103. Trustee's sale; notice.

Notice of sale mentioned in W.S. 34-3-102 shall in every case be the same as the notice provided in W.S. 34-4-104.

History.

Laws 1877, p. 95, § 3; R.S. 1887, § 54; R.S. 1899, § 2798; C.S. 1910, § 3690; C.S. 1920, § 4648; Laws 1931, ch. 73, § 65; R.S. 1931, § 71-220; C.S. 1945, § 59-303; W.S. 1957, § 34-65.

Quoted in

Baldwin v. Dube, 751 P.2d 388, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 64 (Wyo. 1988).

§ 34-3-104. Trustee’s sale; form of deed for auctioned realty.

Every deed for real estate sold under a deed of trust may be made in the following form, or to the same effect:

This deed, made the day of between A. B., trustee, of the first part, and C. D., of the second part, whereas the said trustee, by virtue of the authority vested in him by the deed of trust hereinafter mentioned (or by an order of the district court of the county of ) made on the day of (as the case may be), did sell as required by law, a certain tract (or lot, as the case may be), of land, situated in the county (or city, town or village, as the case may be), of conveyed by E. F. to the said A. B., trustee (or to G. H., trustee, as the case may be), by deed bearing date the day of , and recorded (if it be recorded), in the office of the recorder of the county of , and bounded and described therein as follows: (Here insert the description and quantity as set forth in the deed of trust and any other description deemed necessary); at which sale the said C. D. became the purchaser for the sum of dollars. Now, therefore, this deed witnesseth that the said trustee hereby conveys and grants to the said C. D. the said real estate hereinbefore described, with all the right, title and interest held by the said E. F. therein, to have and to hold the said real estate and premises unto the said C. D., his heirs and assigns forever. Witness the following signature and seal. (Seal.)

Click to view

History.

Laws 1877, p. 96, § 4; R.S. 1887, § 55; R.S. 1899, § 2799; C.S. 1910, § 3691; C.S. 1920, § 4649; R.S. 1931, § 71-221; C.S. 1945, § 59-304; W.S. 1957, § 34-66; 2019, ch. 3, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to form of warranty deed, see § 34-2-102.

As to form of quitclaim deed, see § 34-2-104.

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, deleted “in deed book ...., on page ....”
