  • § 34-4-107.  Manner in which distinct tracts or lots sold.
  • § 34-4-108.  Mortgagee may purchase; by whom sale made; mortgagee, judgment creditor or lienor shall be present or waive.
  • § 34-4-109.  Postponement of sale.
  • § 34-4-110.  Successor to officer making sale may execute conveyance.
  • § 34-4-111.  Costs and expenses; generally.
  • § 34-4-112.  Costs and expenses; attorney's fees.
  • § 34-4-113.  Payment of proceeds.

Cross references. —

As to deeds, mortgages and leases generally, see chapter 2 of this title. See also the cross references at the beginning of chapter 2 of this title.

As to deeds of trust, see chapter 3 of this title.

As to trustee's sale under deed of trust, see §§ 34-3-102 to 34-3-104.

As to venue in action for the sale of real property under a mortgage, lien or other encumbrance or charge, see § 1-5-101.

As to sale and redemption of real property sold under mortgage or execution, see §§ 1-18-101 to 1-18-112.

As to amount and priority of lien acquired by purchase at tax sale, and as to civil action to foreclose same, see § 39-13-108.

As to foreclosure of tax connection with irrigation and drainage districts generally, see §§ 41-6-503 to 41-6-507.

Remedy of mortgagee. —

A mortgagee's only remedy upon mortgage default is foreclosure and public sale, either by power of sale pursuant to this article or by judicial sale in accordance with § 1-18-101 et seq. Sannerud v. Brantz, 928 P.2d 477, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 173 (Wyo. 1996).

Deficiency judgment allowed when foreclosure proper. —

Deficiency judgments after foreclosure by advertisement and sale, on deeds of trust or purchase money mortgages, are allowed when the foreclosure and sale was proper and equitable. Fitch v. Buffalo Fed. Sav. & Loan Ass'n, 751 P.2d 1309, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1988).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Real Estate — The Wyoming Installment Land Contract: A Mortgage in Sheep's Clothing? or What You See Isn't What You Get. Metropolitan Mortgage & Securities Co. v. Belgrade, 816 P.2d 868, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 130 (Wyo. 1991),” see XXVIII Land & Water L. Rev. 309 (1993).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

54 Am. Jur. 2d Mortgages §§ 512 to 942.

Estoppel of or waiver by parties or participants regarding irregularities in foreclosure sale, 2 A.L.R.2d 6.

Cost of foreclosure as covered by guaranty of payment at maturity, 4 ALR2d 138.

What constitutes “public sale,” 4 ALR2d 575.

Attachment, garnishment, execution or similar process in action of note or bond, not resulting in sale of mortgaged property, as precluding foreclosure of real estate mortgage, 37 ALR2d 959.

Effect of purchase of property by pledgee on foreclosure of mortgage held as collateral security, 37 ALR2d 1381.

Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act of 1940, as amended, as affecting foreclosure of mortgages and trust deeds, 40 ALR2d 1262.

Foreclosure of mortgage or trust deed as affecting easement claimed in, over or under property, 46 ALR2d 1197.

Effect of foreclosure on dedication of land by mortgagor, 63 ALR2d 1160.

Propriety of appointing receiver, at behest of mortgagee, to manage or operate property during foreclosure action, 82 ALR2d 1075.

Mortgagor's interference with property subject to order of foreclosure and sale as contempt of court, 54 ALR3d 1242.

Failure to keep up insurance as justifying foreclosure under acceleration provision in mortgage or deed of trust, 69 ALR3d 774.

Validity and enforceability of due-on-sale real-estate mortgage provisions, 61 ALR4th 1070.

Mortgage foreclosure forbearance statutes — modern status, 83 ALR4th 243.

Discharge of mortgage and taking back of new mortgage as affecting lien intervening between old and new mortgages, 43 ALR5th 519.

59 C.J.S. Mortgages §§ 490 to 574; 59A C.J.S. Mortgages 575 to 990.

§ 34-4-101. Application.

The provisions of this act [§§ 34-4-101 through 34-4-109, 34-4-111, 34-4-113] shall apply to all mortgages containing a power of sale executed prior to the passage thereof, not having been foreclosed, and nothing in this act contained shall be construed as limiting the power of parties to a mortgage to provide therein as they may see fit as to the manner of foreclosure and sale, and when such provision is made, foreclosure and sale may be made in accordance therewith, or in accordance with the provisions of this act.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 72, § 16; R.S. 1887, § 51; R.S. 1899, § 2794; C.S. 1910, § 3686; C.S. 1920, § 4644; R.S. 1931, § 71-216; C.S. 1945, § 59-213; W.S. 1957, § 34-67.

Applied in

National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (1948); McNeill Family Trust v. Centura Bank, 2003 WY 2, 60 P.3d 1277, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 2 (Wyo. 2003).

Cited in

In re Various Water Rights in Lake De Smet Reservoir, 623 P.2d 764, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 288 (Wyo. 1981); Cliff & Co. v. Anderson, 777 P.2d 595, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 173 (Wyo. 1989); Resolution Trust Corp. v. Love, 36 F.3d 972, 1994 U.S. App. LEXIS 27000 (10th Cir. 1994).

Law reviews. —

For comment, “Superfund — Your Friendly Hometown Lender? The Liability of Financial Institutions under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act,” see XXIV Land & Water L. Rev. 493 (1989).

§ 34-4-102. Foreclosure by advertisement.

  1. Every mortgage of real estate, containing therein a power of sale upon default being made in any condition thereof, may be foreclosed by advertisement within ten (10) years after the maturing of such mortgage or the debt secured thereby, or after the recording thereof, in the cases and in the manner hereinafter specified.
  2. The time within which such proceeding may be commenced under the power of sale shall begin to run:
    1. As to any mortgage executed after May 21, 1945, from the date of such mortgage, unless the maturity of the debt or obligation secured by such mortgage be clearly stated in or is otherwise readily ascertainable from the provisions of such mortgage;
      1. As to any mortgage executed prior to May 21, 1945, at the latest of the following dates: (ii) (A) As to any mortgage executed prior to May 21, 1945, at the latest of the following dates:
        1. The tenth anniversary of the maturity of the debt or obligation secured by such mortgage if clearly stated in or otherwise readily ascertainable from the provisions of the mortgage;
        2. The tenth anniversary of the recording of the mortgage if no such maturity date is clearly stated in or readily ascertainable from the provisions of the mortgage;
        3. The stated, renewed, or extended maturity date recorded on or before December 31, 1971, in the manner provided in subdivision (B)(II) of this paragraph.
      2. The owner and holder of any debt or obligation secured by a mortgage executed prior to May 21, 1945, the maturity date of which either:
        1. Is not clearly stated or otherwise readily ascertainable; or
        2. Has been renewed or extended by agreement, payment, or other act of the debtor, may, on or before December 31, 1971, record in the office of the county clerk in the county in which such real estate is located either:
          1. An agreement signed and acknowledged by the debtor as a conveyance of real estate, stating the agreed, renewed or extended maturity date of such debt or obligation; or
          2. An affidavit of the owner and holder of such debt or obligation, stating such maturity date and the date, form or manner of the agreement, payment or other act of the debtor fixing such date.
  3. No mortgage in which the maturity of the debt or obligation is not clearly stated or otherwise readily ascertainable, which was recorded on or before May 21, 1945, and for which no stated, renewed or extended maturity date is recorded on or before December 31, 1971, may be foreclosed by advertisement after December 31, 1971; and no such mortgage recorded after May 21, 1945, may be foreclosed by advertisement commenced more than ten (10) years after the date of such recording.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 72, § 1; R.S. 1887, § 36; R.S. 1899, § 2778; C.S. 1910, § 3670; C.S. 1920, § 4627; R.S. 1931, § 71-205; Laws 1945, ch. 122, § 1; C.S. 1945, § 59-201; W.S. 1957, § 34-68; Laws 1971, ch. 152, § 1.

The 1945 amendment to this section operates prospectively and not retroactively. National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1948).

And does not apply to mortgage maturing prior to its enactment. —

Where a mortgage containing a power of sale had matured prior to the enactment of the 1945 amendment to this section, contention was held without merit that the section as amended did apply. National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1948).

Methods of foreclosing mortgages. —

Under Wyoming law two methods of foreclosing mortgages are customarily used, one by an action in court and the other by the exercise of a power of sale under this section and §§ 34-4-101 and 34-4-103 to 34-4-113, when that is given by the terms of the instrument. National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1948).

Avoiding foreclosure. —

Mortgagor and mortgagee may make fair contract avoiding necessity of foreclosure. Ditto v. Bank of Gillette, 38 Wyo. 120, 264 P. 1013, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1928); Fitch v. Ditto, 38 Wyo. 134, 264 P. 1017, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1928).

Sale valid although personalty sold was not advertised. —

A sale of mortgaged real estate under a power of sale was valid though advertisement did not state that personal property consisting of liquors, tobaccos and beverages was also to be sold where both the deed and the mortgage included the liquor, tobaccos and beverages as a part of the described real estate. Hill v. Salmon, 69 Wyo. 1, 236 P.2d 518, 1951 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1951).

Whether deed construed as mortgage. —

Where a mortgagor, being unable to pay the debt, executed an absolute deed to the property to the mortgagees, who received deed in payment of the debt and agreed that, in case the property should sell for more than enough to pay their claim, interest, taxes, etc., they would account to the mortgagor for the surplus, conveyance could not be treated as a mortgage in equity. Weltner v. Thurmond, 17 Wyo. 268, 98 P. 590, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 17 Wyo. 310, 98 P. 601, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 1908).

Contract recitals of prior indebtedness and giving of deed in payment to avoid foreclosure are entitled to consideration on issue whether deed should be declared mortgage. Ditto v. Bank of Gillette, 38 Wyo. 120, 264 P. 1013, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1928); Fitch v. Ditto, 38 Wyo. 134, 264 P. 1017, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1928).

Mortgagors not repurchasing property within contract time are not entitled to have deed, made to avoid foreclosure, declared mortgage in action brought just before time expired. Ditto v. Bank of Gillette, 38 Wyo. 120, 264 P. 1013, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1928); Fitch v. Ditto, 38 Wyo. 134, 264 P. 1017, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1928).

Mortgagors' promise to repurchase land would not require finding that deed, executed to avoid foreclosure, was intended as security for debt. Ditto v. Bank of Gillette, 38 Wyo. 120, 264 P. 1013, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1928); Fitch v. Ditto, 38 Wyo. 134, 264 P. 1017, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1928).

Parties executing deed, with right of repurchase, to avoid expense of foreclosure, were not entitled to have it declared a mortgage. Ditto v. Bank of Gillette, 38 Wyo. 120, 264 P. 1013, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1928); Fitch v. Ditto, 38 Wyo. 134, 264 P. 1017, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1928).

Formerly section did not provide time limit for exercising power of sale. —

Prior to the amendment of this section by ch. 122, Laws 1945, there was no statute limiting the time within which the right to exercise a power of sale contained in a mortgage or trust deed might be invoked. National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1948).

Applied in

Ferguson v. Haygood, 67 Wyo. 422, 225 P.2d 336, 1950 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (1950).

Law reviews. —

For a note dealing with limitation on foreclosure of a real estate mortgage by advertisement under a bill of sale, see 1 Wyo. L.J. 129.

§ 34-4-103. Prerequisites to foreclosure.

  1. To entitle any party to give a notice as hereinafter prescribed and to make such foreclosure, it is requisite:
    1. That some default in a condition of such mortgage has occurred by which the power to sell became operative;
    2. That no suit or proceeding has been instituted at law to recover the debt then remaining secured by such mortgage, or any part thereof, or if any suit or proceeding has been instituted, that the same has been discontinued, or that an execution upon the judgment rendered therein has been returned unsatisfied in whole or in part;
    3. That the mortgage containing the power of sale has been duly recorded; and if it has been assigned, that all assignments have been recorded; and
    4. That written notice of intent to foreclose the mortgage by advertisement and sale has been served upon the record owner, and the person in possession of the mortgaged premises if different than the record owner, by certified mail with return receipt, mailed to the last known address of the record owner and the person in possession at least ten (10) days before commencement of publication of notice of sale. Proof of compliance with this subsection shall be by affidavit.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 72, § 2; R.S. 1887, § 37; R.S. 1899, § 2779; C.S. 1910, § 3671; C.S. 1920, § 4628; R.S. 1931, § 71-206; C.S. 1945, § 59-202; W.S. 1957, § 34-69; Laws 1977, ch. 123, § 1; 2006, ch. 114, § 1.

Actual notice. —

Strict compliance with the notice requirement of this section is unnecessary when a party has actual notice of intent to foreclose. ORO Mgmt., LLC v. R.C. Mineral & Rock, LLC, 2013 WY 77, 304 P.3d 925, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 81 (Wyo. 2013).

In an action to set aside a foreclosure sale, the district court properly granted summary judgment for the assignee of the mortgage; the failure by the assignee of the mortgage to send written notice of its intent to foreclose to the property owner did not provide a legal basis to set aside the summary judgment as the property owner had actual notice. ORO Mgmt., LLC v. R.C. Mineral & Rock, LLC, 2013 WY 77, 304 P.3d 925, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 81 (Wyo. 2013).

Cross references. —

As to recordation of conveyances generally, see §§ 34-1-118 to 34-1-123.

As to recording assignments of mortgages, see § 34-1-128.

The 2006 amendment, deleted “and” at the end of (a)(ii).

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 24, 2006.

Editor's notes. —

Senate Enrolled Act No. 107 of the 1989 general session of the legislature purported to amend this section so as to add additional prerequisites to foreclosure, relating to those persons who are entitled to receive notice, but this bill was vetoed by the governor.

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 3, provides: “[A]ny other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

The term “proceeding” as used in this section is a broad term, but its meaning is limited in the section, and must be one instituted at law. Denver Joint Stock Land Bank v. Preston, 52 Wyo. 132, 70 P.2d 584, 1937 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 1937).

Filing claim against estate as not precluding foreclosure. —

Filing of claim against an estate is in the nature of a demand, a condition precedent to commencement of action, and does not constitute commencement of an action so as to preclude the foreclosure of a mortgage under a power of sale contained therein. Denver Joint Stock Land Bank v. Preston, 52 Wyo. 132, 70 P.2d 584, 1937 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 1937).

Actual notice. —

There is no provision in subsection (a)(iv) that prohibits actual notice of intent to foreclose other than by mailing to the last known address of the record owner. Walker v. McAnnany, 802 P.2d 876, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1990).

Mortgagor who had actual notice from his partner of the mortgagee's intent to foreclose was not prejudiced by his having actual notice rather than receiving a notice by certified mail. Walker v. McAnnany, 802 P.2d 876, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1990).

Prerequisites satisfied. —

Summary judgment in favor of a bank on a landowner's fraudulent foreclosure claim was proper where the landowner did not make payments on the promissory note, no lawsuit or proceeding was instituted to recover the debt, and the bank wrote him a letter, which constituted actual notice of the assignment of the promissory note and the pending foreclosure on the property. Bitker v. First Nat'l Bank, 2004 WY 114, 98 P.3d 853, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 148 (Wyo. 2004).

Mortgagee was entitled to rely on the mortgagor's address listed in the purchase agreement, and was not required to make an extensive search for a new address when the notice of intent to foreclose, sent by certified mail, was returned with a notation that the mortgagor had moved and left no forwarding address. Walker v. McAnnany, 802 P.2d 876, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1990).

Notice to corporation's officers not satisfactory. —

Statutory notice furnished to individuals who were officers (one of whom also was a director and counsel) of a corporation did not satisfy the statutory requirement of notice to the corporation. Ulery-Williams, Inc. v. First Wyo. Bank, N.A.-Laramie, 748 P.2d 740, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1988).

Foreclosure invalid if mortgage not recorded. —

Under this section a mortgage foreclosure sale by advertisement under power of sale contained in the mortgage is invalid as between the parties, unless the mortgage containing such power has been fully recorded and, as a prerequisite, such mortgage must have been entitled to record. Harney v. Montgomery, 29 Wyo. 362, 213 P. 378, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1923).

Summary judgment setting aside foreclosure reversed. —

Summary judgment in favor of the mortgagee, setting aside a foreclosure sale of real property, was reversed because the mortgagee did not come with clean hands, it failed to show that it had no adequate remedy at law, and the parties could not have been substantially returned to their presale status. McNeill Family Trust v. Centura Bank, 2003 WY 2, 60 P.3d 1277, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 2 (Wyo. 2003).

Applied in

National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (1948).

§ 34-4-104. Publication and service of notices; generally.

  1. Notice that the mortgage will be foreclosed by a sale of the mortgaged premises, or some part of them, shall be given by publishing the notice for four (4) consecutive weeks, at least once in each week, in a newspaper printed in the county where the premises included in the mortgage and intended to be sold, or some part of them, are situated, if there be one; and if no newspaper be printed in the county, then notice shall be published in a paper printed in the state and of general circulation in the county. Prior to first date of publication, a copy of the notice shall be served by certified mail with return receipt requested upon the record owner, the person in possession of mortgaged premises, if different than the record owner, and all holders of recorded mortgages and liens subordinate to the mortgage being foreclosed, which appear of record at least twenty-five (25) days before the scheduled foreclosure sale. The notice shall be sent to the last known address for the addressee, which shall be the address set forth in the mortgage or lien filed of record unless another address has been recorded in the real estate records or has been provided to the foreclosing mortgagee or lienholder. Proof of compliance with this section shall be made by affidavit of an authorized representative of the foreclosing mortgagee or lienholder. A person or entity who acts in reliance upon the affidavit without knowledge that the representations contained therein are incorrect shall not be liable to any person for so acting and may assume without inquiry the existence of the facts contained in the affidavit.
  2. If there are sale proceeds in excess of the amount necessary to pay the foreclosing mortgagee, judgment creditor or other lienor in full, then within ten (10) business days following the sale of real estate by foreclosure, the foreclosing mortgagee or lienholder shall serve a copy of the sale results to the record owner of the mortgaged premises and all holders of recorded mortgages and liens subordinate to the mortgage or lien being foreclosed. Sale results shall be sent by certified mail with return receipt requested to the last known address for the addressee, which shall be the address set forth in the mortgage or lien filed of record unless another address has been recorded in the real estate records or has been provided in writing to the foreclosing mortgagee or lienholder. The sale results shall include the amount due the foreclosing mortgagee or lienholder as of the date of sale, the name of the successful bidder and the amount of the successful bid. If the certificate of sale awarded to the successful bidder includes the required information, the foreclosing mortgagee or lienholder may comply with this section by serving a copy of the certificate of sale.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 72, § 3; R.S. 1887, § 38; R.S. 1899, § 2780; C.S. 1910, § 3672; C.S. 1920, § 4629; Laws 1931, ch. 73, § 64; R.S. 1931, § 71-207; C.S. 1945, § 59-203; W.S. 1957, § 34-70; Laws 2005, ch. 228, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to application of this section to sales under deeds of trust, see § 34-3-103.

As to publication of notices required by law, see §§ 1-6-201 to 1-6-204.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, and applicable to real estate mortgage foreclosures and execution sales commenced on or after that date, redesignated former undesignated paragraph as (a), and in (a), added the last four sentences; added (b); and made stylistic changes.

Mortgagor not deprived of substantial right by shortening time for publication. —

Shortening time for publication of notice of mortgage foreclosure sale, from 6 weeks to 4 weeks, does not deprive mortgagor of any substantial right as it does not shorten period of redemption, although it does shorten by 2 weeks the period which the mortgagor may remain in possession. James v. Chapman, 50 Wyo. 210, 58 P.2d 439, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1936).

Applied in

National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (1948); McNeill Family Trust v. Centura Bank, 2003 WY 2, 60 P.3d 1277, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 2 (Wyo. 2003).

§ 34-4-105. Publication of notice; contents.

  1. Every such notice shall include:
    1. The names of the mortgagor and of the mortgagee and the assignee of the mortgage if any;
    2. The date of the mortgage and when recorded;
    3. The amount claimed to be due thereon at the date of the notice;
    4. A description of the mortgaged premises, conforming substantially with that contained in the mortgage;
    5. The time and place of sale; and
    6. A statement that “The property being foreclosed upon may be subject to other liens and encumbrances that will not be extinguished at the sale and any prospective purchaser should research the status of title before submitting a bid.”

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 72, § 4; R.S. 1887, § 39; R.S. 1899, § 2781; C.S. 1910, § 3673; C.S. 1920, § 4630; R.S. 1931, § 71-208; C.S. 1945, § 59-204; W.S. 1957, § 34-71; Laws 2005, ch. 228, § 2.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, and applicable to real estate mortgage foreclosures and execution sales commenced on or after that date, in (a), substituted “include” for “specify”; added (a)(vi); and made stylistic changes.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Statement of recordation. —

The notice of foreclosure must contain a statement as to when the mortgage was recorded. Harney v. Montgomery, 29 Wyo. 362, 213 P. 378, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1923).

Heading and signature not required. —

This section requires five (now six) items of information to be included in a foreclosure notice. Neither a heading nor a signature is required. Williams v. First Wyo. Bank, N.A., 742 P.2d 197, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 503 (Wyo. 1987).

Applied in

National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (1948).

Cited in

Hill v. Salmon, 69 Wyo. 1, 236 P.2d 518, 1951 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (1951).

§ 34-4-106. Time, place and manner of sale generally; mortgagee, judgment creditor or lienor shall be present or waive.

The sale shall be at public vendue, between the hour of ten (10:00) o’clock in the forenoon, and five (5:00) o’clock in the afternoon, at the front door of the courthouse, or the place of holding the district court of the county within the county in which the premises to be sold, or some part of them, are situated, and shall be made by the person appointed for that purpose in the mortgage or by the sheriff or deputy sheriff of the county, to the highest bidder. The sheriff or deputy sheriff shall not hold the sale unless the foreclosing mortgagee, judgment creditor, other foreclosing lienor or an authorized agent of the foreclosing party is present at the sale or has previously waived to the sheriff conducting the sale the right to appear and bid at the sale. The sheriff conducting the sale shall not be considered to be the authorized agent of the foreclosing party unless the foreclosing party has given the sheriff a specified opening bid to be presented by the sheriff on behalf of the foreclosing party and the sheriff actually presents the opening bid. Any foreclosure sale conducted without complying with the terms of this section is void, in which case the mortgage, power of sale, judgment or other lien which is the subject of the voided sale is not extinguished or exhausted, but may be properly foreclosed in a subsequent foreclosure sale in compliance with applicable law.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 72, § 5; R.S. 1887, § 40; R.S. 1899, § 2782; C.S. 1910, § 3674; C.S. 1920, § 4631; R.S. 1931, § 71-209; C.S. 1945, § 59-205; W.S. 1957, § 34-72; Laws 2005, ch. 228, § 2.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, and applicable to real estate mortgage foreclosures and execution sales commenced on or after that date, substituted “ten (10:00) o'clock” for “nine (9:00)”, and added the last three sentences.

Sale by undersheriff valid. —

An undersheriff is in effect a deputy sheriff, so that a sale and deed executed by such undersheriff is valid. Delfelder v. Teton Land & Inv. Co., 46 Wyo. 142, 24 P.2d 702, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 46 Wyo. 142, 26 P.2d 153, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 1933).

Deed executed by undersheriff valid. —

Undersheriff acting as auctioneer also acted as deputy sheriff and had authority to execute a deed, as he is not a mortgage holder. Delfelder v. Teton Land & Inv. Co., 46 Wyo. 142, 24 P.2d 702, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 46 Wyo. 142, 26 P.2d 153, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 1933).

Applied in

National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (1948).

Quoted in

Kottcamp v. Fleet Real Estate Funding Corp., 783 P.2d 170, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 228 (Wyo. 1989).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

What constitutes public sale, 4 ALR2d 575.

§ 34-4-107. Manner in which distinct tracts or lots sold.

If the mortgaged premises consist of distinct tracts or lots the foreclosing mortgagee may offer for sale separately sufficient tracts or lots as shall be necessary to satisfy the amount due on such mortgage at the date of the notice of sale, with interest and costs and expenses allowed by law, or the foreclosing mortgagee may offer all such distinct tracts or lots to be sold as a whole.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 72, § 7; R.S. 1887, § 42; R.S. 1899, § 2784; C.S. 1910, § 3676; C.S. 1920, § 4633; Laws 1931, ch. 43, § 1; R.S. 1931, § 71-211; C.S. 1945, § 59-207; W.S. 1957, § 34-73; 2011, ch. 173, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to redemption of property in parcels, see § 1-18-105.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, rewrote the section by substituting “the foreclosing mortgagee may offer” for “they shall be first offered,” “sufficient tracts or lots as shall be” for “and no more tracts or lots shall be sold than shall be,” and “or the foreclosing mortgagee may offer all such distinct tracts or lots to be” for “provided, however, that in the event the aggregate of bids on such distinct tracts or lots is not sufficient to satisfy said amount due, all such distinct tracts or lots shall be offered and.”

Provision requiring distinct tracts to be sold separately does not apply to proceedings in court where confirmation of foreclosure sale must be had and parties are afforded full opportunity to object to manner in which sale was conducted. Bank of Commerce v. Williams, 52 Wyo. 1, 69 P.2d 525, 1937 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 1937).

Applied in

National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (1948).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Foreclosure sale of mortgaged real estate as whole or in parcels, 61 ALR2d 505.

§ 34-4-108. Mortgagee may purchase; by whom sale made; mortgagee, judgment creditor or lienor shall be present or waive.

The mortgagee, his assigns, or his or their legal representatives may fairly and in good faith, purchase the premises sold upon foreclosure of any mortgage by advertisement under power of sale or any part thereof, at the sale; and whenever the mortgage shall provide for the mortgagee to sell the premises at the foreclosure sale, notwithstanding the provision, the sale may be made by the sheriff, or deputy sheriff, or by the mortgagee at the option of the latter. The sale shall be postponed, if the foreclosing mortgagee, judgment creditor or other foreclosing lienor, or an authorized agent of the foreclosing mortgagee, judgment creditor or other foreclosing lienor, is not present at the sale or has not previously waived in writing the right to appear and bid at the sale.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 72, § 8; R.S. 1887, § 43; R.S. 1899, § 2785; C.S. 1910, § 3677; C.S. 1920, § 4634; R.S. 1931, § 71-212; C.S. 1945, § 59-208; W.S. 1957, § 34-74; Laws 2005, ch. 228, § 2.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, and applicable to real estate mortgage foreclosures and execution sales commenced on or after that date, added the last sentence and made stylistic changes.

Claim for breach of duty of good faith. —

In a complaint for declaratory relief, mortgagee of a second mortgage on a property failed to state a claim upon which relief could be granted for breach of a duty of good faith on the part of the mortgagee of the first mortgage that purchased the property at foreclosure sale but paid less than fair value where the complaint alleged the latter purchased the subject property for an amount it knew to be less than the property's true value, but did not allege either fraud, partiality, or oppression, that the sale was conducted illegally, or that there was less than a full and fair opportunity for competitive bidding. Manion v. Chase Manhattan Mortg. Corp., 2002 WY 49, 43 P.3d 576, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2002).

Deed executed by undersheriff valid. —

An undersheriff is in effect a deputy sheriff, so that a sale and deed executed by such undersheriff is valid. Delfelder v. Teton Land & Inv. Co., 46 Wyo. 142, 24 P.2d 702, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 46 Wyo. 142, 26 P.2d 153, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 1933).

The undersheriff acting as auctioneer also acted as deputy sheriff and had authority to execute a deed, as he is not a mortgage holder. Delfelder v. Teton Land & Inv. Co., 46 Wyo. 142, 24 P.2d 702, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 46 Wyo. 142, 26 P.2d 153, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 1933).

Presence of mortgagee not required. —

There is no indication in the statutes that a foreclosure sale is invalid if the mortgagee<=nder does not attend the sale. McNeill Family Trust v. Centura Bank, 2003 WY 2, 60 P.3d 1277, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 2 (Wyo. 2003).

Applied in

National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (1948).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Effect of purchase of property by pledgee on foreclosure of mortgage holder's collateral security, 37 ALR2d 1381.

§ 34-4-109. Postponement of sale.

A foreclosure sale may be postponed from time to time by inserting a notice of the postponement as soon as practicable in the newspaper in which the original advertisement was published and continuing the publication until the time to which the sale shall be postponed, at the expense of the party requesting the postponement, provided that the original advertisement is published at least once a week, over four (4) consecutive weeks, and the notice of postponement is published at least once a week, over two (2) consecutive weeks.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 72, § 6; R.S. 1887, § 41; R.S. 1899, § 2783; C.S. 1910, § 3675; C.S. 1920, § 4632; R.S. 1931, § 71-210; C.S. 1945, § 59-206; W.S. 1957, § 34-75; Laws 2005, ch. 228, § 2.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, and applicable to real estate mortgage foreclosures and execution sales commenced on or after that date, substituted “A foreclosure sale” for “Such sale,” added the proviso, and made stylistic changes.

Applied in

National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (1948).

§ 34-4-110. Successor to officer making sale may execute conveyance.

If the term of service of the officer who makes sale of any lands and tenements as provided in chapter 243 of the Wyoming Compiled Statutes of 1910 expires, or if such officer die, be absent or unable for any cause to make a deed of conveyance of the property sold, any successor of such officer may execute such conveyance.

History.

Laws 1915, ch. 27, § 1; C.S. 1920, § 4637; R.S. 1931, § 89-2973; C.S. 1945, § 59-209; W.S. 1957, § 34-76.

Cross references. —

For authority of succeeding officer to make deed in connection with lien of judgment, see § 1-17-329.

As to execution of process by sheriff and deputies, see § 18-3-604.

Editor's notes. —

“Chapter 243 of the Wyoming Compiled Statutes of 1910,” appears herein as §§ 34-1-105, 34-1-122, 34-1-130, 34-2-107 to 34-2-113, 34-2-124, 34-3-101 to 34-4-109, 34-4-111 and 34-4-113.

Savings clauses. —

Section 2, Laws 1915, ch. 27, read: “All deeds of conveyance heretofore executed in this state in conformity with the provision of the foregoing section are hereby legalized and made binding upon the parties in interest in all respects.”

Applied in

National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (1948).

§ 34-4-111. Costs and expenses; generally.

The costs and expenses of the foreclosure sale, which shall be paid out of the proceeds of the sale, shall include the costs of advertising, the fee of the officer or person making the sale and executing the deed, said fee not to exceed ten dollars ($10.00); and an attorney or solicitor’s fee if there be a stipulation therefor in the mortgage.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 72, § 10; R.S. 1887, § 45; R.S. 1899, § 2788; C.S. 1910, § 3680; C.S. 1920, § 4638; R.S. 1931, § 71-213; C.S. 1945, § 59-210; W.S. 1957, § 34-77.

Attorney's fee. —

Costs and expenses, including attorney's fee, in mortgages, when so provided for, are contractual rights, and part of indebtedness to be satisfied, provided such right has accrued, and the right then continues, without regard to any form that a resulting action may take. Yellowstone Sheep Co. v. Ellis, 55 Wyo. 63, 96 P.2d 895, 1939 Wyo. LEXIS 43 (Wyo. 1939).

Applied in

National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (1948).

§ 34-4-112. Costs and expenses; attorney's fees.

Whenever an attorney’s fee is provided for in any real or chattel mortgage, or the note or notes secured thereby, such attorney’s fee shall not be allowed or added to the mortgage debt in any foreclosure by public advertisement and sale, unless it shall appear by the affidavit of an attorney admitted generally to practice in this state representing the mortgagee or his assigns in such foreclosures, or the party instituting such foreclosure, which affidavit shall be filed with the sheriff or person who shall conduct the sale under such foreclosure, and said affidavit shall state therein that there has been and is no agreement, express or implied, between such attorney and his client, nor between him and any other person except a practicing attorney of this state engaged with him as an attorney in the foreclosure proceeding, for any sharing or division of said fee so to be allowed or added to the debt involved, and said fee when so allowed or added to the debt shall be only as compensation for services actually rendered in the foreclosure proceeding by an attorney admitted to practice in this state and residing therein. Provided, however, that in the foreclosure of real estate mortgages, this section shall in no wise affect the title to the real estate involved in such a foreclosure.

History.

Laws 1927, ch. 102, § 1; R.S. 1931, § 71-214; C.S. 1945, § 59-211; W.S. 1957, § 34-78.

Attorney fees are contractual rights. —

Costs and expenses, including attorney's fee, in mortgages, when so provided for, are contractual rights, and part of indebtedness to be satisfied, provided such right has accrued, and right then continues, without regard to any form that resulting action may take. Yellowstone Sheep Co. v. Ellis, 55 Wyo. 63, 96 P.2d 895, 1939 Wyo. LEXIS 43 (Wyo. 1939).

Foreclosure notice overstating attorney fees not fraudulent. —

Where mortgage foreclosure notice stated $3,500 was due as attorney's fees and only $1,250 was actually paid, it was held not fraudulent. Delfelder v. Teton Land & Inv. Co., 46 Wyo. 142, 24 P.2d 702, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 46 Wyo. 142, 26 P.2d 153, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 1933).

Applied in

National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (1948).

Quoted in

Burk v. Burzynski, 672 P.2d 419, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 385 (Wyo. 1983).

§ 34-4-113. Payment of proceeds.

  1. After any sale of real estate made as herein prescribed, proceeds from the sale shall be paid over by the officer or other person making the sale in the following order:
    1. Payment of the reasonable expenses of collection and enforcement and, to the extent provided by law, reasonable attorney’s fees and legal expenses incurred by the foreclosing mortgagee;
    2. The satisfaction of obligations secured by the mortgage being foreclosed;
    3. The satisfaction of obligations secured by any subordinate or junior mortgage or other lien on the real estate sold at the foreclosure sale; and
    4. Surplus proceeds on demand to the mortgagor, his legal representatives or assigns, and if no demand is made, then the foreclosing mortgagee, officer or other person making sale may retain the surplus proceeds for disposition to the mortgagor or may dispose of the surplus proceeds in accordance with W.S. 34-24-101 et seq.
  2. If the foreclosing mortgagee receives a demand for the proceeds accompanied by the materials required by W.S. 1-18-104(c) and signed by the holder of a subordinate or junior mortgage or other lien within thirty (30) days after the results of the sale are served in accordance with W.S. 34-4-104, proceeds remaining after distribution under paragraphs (a)(i) and (ii) of this section shall be paid over by the officer or other person making the sale as agreed upon by all parties in interest, or by court order, to the subordinate mortgagees or lienholders in accordance with their priority and to the extent of their interest.
  3. Subject to the other provisions of this section, a mortgagee shall account to and pay a mortgagor for any surplus, and the mortgagor is liable for any deficiency.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 72,§ 11; R.S. 1887, § 46; R.S. 1899, § 2789; C.S. 1910, § 3681; C.S. 1920, § 4639; R.S. 1931, § 71-215; C.S. 1945, § 59-212; W.S. 1957, § 34-79; Laws 2005, ch. 228, § 2.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, and applicable to real estate mortgage foreclosures and execution sales commenced on or after July 1, 2005, rewrote this section, which formerly read: “If after any sale of real estate made as herein prescribed, there shall remain in the hands of the officer or other person making the sale any surplus money after satisfying the mortgage on which such real estate was sold and payment of the costs and expenses of such foreclosure and sale, the surplus shall be paid over by such officer or other person on demand to the mortgagor, his legal representatives or assigns.”

Deficiency judgment.—

District court did not err in ruling that a lender was entitled to a deficiency judgment because consent and confirmation orders did not alter a limited liability company (LLC) member’s obligations under a Wyoming judgment the lender obtained against the member and LLC for the outstanding balance of a loan; the member was not a party to the LLC’s bankruptcy case, and thus, he was not entitled to the benefits the LLC obtained through the bankruptcy process. Thomas v. JLC Wyo., LLC, 2019 WY 14, 434 P.3d 104, 2019 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 2019).

Applied in

National Tailoring Co. v. Scott, 65 Wyo. 64, 196 P.2d 387, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (1948).

“Lien theory” mortgage foreclosure scheme. —

In this foreclosure action, the grant of summary judgment to the bank was affirmed; the full amount of the finance company's bid must be applied to the secured debt because under Wyoming law, and by the finance company's own admission, the effect of a successful credit bid was to satisfy and discharge a mortgage. Republic Bank of Chi. v. 1st Republic Bank of Chi. v. 1st Advantage Bank, 2013 IL App (1st) 120885, 376 Ill. Dec. 366, 999 N.E.2d 9, 2013 Ill. App. LEXIS 630 (Ill. App. Ct. 1st Dist. 2013).

Law reviews. —

For comment, “Superfund — Your Friendly Hometown Lender? The Liability of Financial Institutions under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act,” see XXIV Land & Water L. Rev. 493 (1989).

Chapter 5 Conveyances Validated

  • § 34-5-101.  When executed out of state; exceptions.
  • § 34-5-102.  Instruments not witnessed; exceptions.
  • § 34-5-103.  Certificate of acknowledgment; failure to state acknowledgment was according to law; liability of county clerk.
  • § 34-5-104.  Certificate of acknowledgment; incomplete.
  • § 34-5-105.  Defects in mortgage releases and assignments; time limits for civil action.
  • § 34-5-106.  When executed by executor; generally.
  • § 34-5-107.  When executed by executor; deceased entryman.
  • § 34-5-108.  Foreign administrator.
  • § 34-5-109.  Copies of proceedings in foreign courts.
  • § 34-5-110.  Adverse claims; when adverse claimant barred against purchaser.
  • § 34-5-111.  Adverse claims; action by heir against purchaser.
  • § 34-5-112.  Effect of preceding sections on pending litigation; enforcement of rights of minor heir in conveyed property.
  • § 34-5-113.  Where release of homestead or marital status of grantor not indicated.
  • § 34-5-114.  Gifts to religious and educational uses; generally.
  • § 34-5-115.  Gifts to religious and educational uses; existence of prior trust agreements in will.
  • § 34-5-116.  Gifts to religious and educational uses; valid notwithstanding terms are included only by reference.
  • § 34-5-117.  Gifts to religious and educational uses; application of W.S. 34-5-114 through 34-5-117.

Cross references. —

For provision that claim of adverse possession shall not invalidate conveyance, see § 34-1-112.

As to force and effect as evidence of conveyances executed prior to 1882, see § 34-1-122.

As to Comprehensive Curative Act, see chapter 8 of this title.

As to validation of plats heretofore filed for record and not subsequently vacated, see § 34-12-101.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Estate created by deed to persons described as husband and wife but not legally married, 9 ALR4th 1189.

§ 34-5-101. When executed out of state; exceptions.

All deeds and conveyances of real estate given and recorded in the state of Wyoming prior to January 1, 1925, the execution of which shall have been acknowledged before a notarial officer out of this state, where the certificate of official character attached to such deeds or other conveyance fails to state that such deed or conveyance was executed and acknowledged according to the laws of the state or territory in which the same was executed, shall be deemed as valid and binding as if such certificate had contained the statement aforesaid, and shall be so construed by the courts, and the record thereof shall have the same force and effect as if such certificate had contained said statement; provided, that such record shall in no wise affect the right or title of any person acquired in good faith and for a valuable consideration before the said January 1, 1925; and provided, further, that this section shall not be construed to affect any judgment or decree rendered by any court of the state before that time.

History.

Laws 1935, ch. 46, § 1; C.S. 1945, § 66-301; W.S. 1957, § 34-80; 2011, ch. 113, § 2.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, substituted “notarial officer” for “notary public.”

Law reviews. —

See comment, “Remedial Title Legislation for Wyoming,” VII Land & Water L. Rev. 561 (1972).

§ 34-5-102. Instruments not witnessed; exceptions.

All deeds, mortgages or other instruments executed five (5) years prior to January 1, 1935, not witnessed, and admitted to record, which, under the laws of the state of Wyoming should have been executed in the presence of one (1) witness, shall be deemed as valid and binding as if the same had been executed in the presence of a witness, and shall be so construed by the courts of this state, and the records thereof shall have the same force and effect as if such deeds, mortgages, and other instruments had been executed in the presence of a witness; provided, that such record shall in no wise affect the right or title of any person acquired in good faith and for a valuable consideration five (5) years before the said 1st day of January, 1935; and provided, further, that this section shall not be construed to affect any judgment or decree rendered by any court of the state of Wyoming before that time.

History.

Laws 1935, ch. 46, § 2; C.S. 1945, § 66-302; W.S. 1957, § 34-81.

§ 34-5-103. Certificate of acknowledgment; failure to state acknowledgment was according to law; liability of county clerk.

All deeds, mortgages, powers of attorney and other instruments executed and acknowledged in any other state, territory or district of the United States five (5) years prior to January 1, 1935, affecting property or property rights in this state, but where the person taking the acknowledgment has omitted to state in his certificate of acknowledgment that such deed, mortgage, power of attorney or other instrument was executed and acknowledged according to the law of such state, territory or district, and when the laws of this state in relation to such certificate have in all other respects been complied with, shall be deemed valid and shall be so construed by the courts of this state, and such instruments shall be entitled to record and the record thereof shall have the same force and effect as if such deeds, mortgages, powers of attorney or other instruments had been acknowledged in the manner provided by the laws of this state, and in case any county clerk shall have received for record such defective instruments, he shall not be liable in an action for damages for having received for record and recorded any such deed, mortgage, power of attorney or other instrument.

History.

Laws 1935, ch. 46, § 3; C.S. 1945, § 66-303; W.S. 1957, § 34-82; Laws 2009, ch. 168, § 206.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, substituted “county clerk” for “register of deeds.”

§ 34-5-104. Certificate of acknowledgment; incomplete.

Any conveyance of real estate made ten (10) years or more prior to January 1st, A.D. 1935, purporting to be acknowledged before any justice of the peace, within or without the state of Wyoming, where such justice of the peace did not state in his certificate of acknowledgment the date of expiration of his office, or where no certificate, or a defective certificate is attached to such deed by the county clerk or clerk of court of the county of such justice of the peace as is required by law in case such acknowledgment is taken before a justice of the peace outside of the state of Wyoming; and any conveyance of real estate made ten (10) years or more prior to January 1st, A.D. 1935, purporting to be acknowledged before any notarial officer, where such notarial officer did not attach his seal to such certificate of acknowledgment, or did not state therein the expiration of the time of his commission; and any conveyance of real estate made ten (10) years or more prior to the 1st day of January, A.D. 1935, where such conveyance does not purport to be properly witnessed; and any conveyance of real estate made ten (10) years or more, prior to the first day of January, A.D. 1935, purporting to be executed by any corporation, where there is any defect or irregularity in the execution or acknowledgment thereof, shall, if the same has been heretofore recorded ten (10) years or more prior to January 1st, 1935, in the office of the county clerk of the county where the real estate therein conveyed is situate, be deemed as valid and as effective and binding as though the defects and irregularities therein, herein mentioned, did not exist and as though in these respects the same had been executed in full accordance with the laws of this state, and the record, or the certified copy thereof, shall be admitted in evidence in all actions or proceedings with the same force and effect as though the defects and irregularities therein, herein mentioned, did not exist, and as though in these respects the same had been executed in full accordance with the laws of this state.

History.

Laws 1935, ch. 46, § 4; C.S. 1945, § 66-304; W.S. 1957, § 34-83; 2011, ch. 113, § 2.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, substituted “notarial officer” for “notary public” twice.

§ 34-5-105. Defects in mortgage releases and assignments; time limits for civil action.

Any and all mortgage releases and assignments of mortgages which have been heretofore recorded in the office of the county clerk of the county wherein the real estate therein is affected is situate, and have been of record five (5) years or more prior to January 1, 1935, purporting to cancel and discharge or assign any mortgage, and purporting to be executed by any mortgagee his agent or attorney, or by any assignee of said mortgage, or purporting to be executed by any person acting for a corporation which is either mortgagee or assignee of said mortgage, shall be deemed to be valid, and the lien of such mortgage, shall be deemed to be canceled in case of release, and the mortgage deemed duly assigned, in case of assignment, notwithstanding any defects in the execution of such release or assignment. Provided, however, that the holder of any mortgage or the assignee thereof, which said mortgage is defectively released, or assigned as hereinbefore specified, and which has remained unchallenged, by the proper action in court, or other legal and proper proceeding, on the records aforesaid for the period of five (5) years or more as aforesaid, shall have until the first day of January, 1936, in which to commence an action in a court of competent jurisdiction in this state, for the assertion and enforcement of his rights, or to set aside such release or assignment, and if not so commenced as herein mentioned, then such release or assignment shall be deemed valid against such persons and all rights as against the same shall be barred.

History.

Laws 1935, ch. 46, § 5; C.S. 1945, § 66-305; W.S. 1957, § 34-84.

§ 34-5-106. When executed by executor; generally.

In all cases where a conveyance of real estate situate in this state has been made by an executor, administrator or administrator de bonis non, of any deceased person, whether appointed and acting in this or any other state, and the fact of the sale or the conveyance of such real estate has been reported to the court in which such executor, administrator or administrator de bonis non was appointed and acting, and the proceeds of such sale or conveyance, or any part thereof have been distributed, it shall be prima facie evidence that the person or persons so receiving said proceeds or any part thereof, either directly or through any agent or assignee, consented to such sale and conveyance, and intended thereby and did thereby, vest in the purchaser under such sale, and the grantee in such conveyance all the right, title and interest which said person or persons, so receiving said proceeds or any part thereof, had in and to the premises so sold and conveyed at the time of such receipt, and did by so receiving such proceeds or any part thereof, intend to be estopped from claiming any further right, title or interest in and to such real estate.

History.

Laws 1935, ch. 46, § 10; C.S. 1945, § 66-310; W.S. 1957, § 34-85.

Equitable title. —

Where 1 of 2 grantees designated in administrator's deed conveying realty died before deed was executed, and consideration paid was retained and disposed of as assets of estate, equitable title passed to deceased grantee's heirs. Black v. Beagle, 59 Wyo. 268, 139 P.2d 439, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 59 Wyo. 268, 139 P.2d 439, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1943).

§ 34-5-107. When executed by executor; deceased entryman.

Any conveyance of land situate within this state, for which no final proof had been made by a deceased entryman or for which no patent had been issued to such deceased entryman under the land laws of the United States during the life of such entryman, which said conveyance has heretofore been made by an executor, administrator or administrator de bonis non of such deceased, appointed and acting by the authority of an order of court of this or any other state, and any conveyance of any land situate in this state heretofore made by any such executor, administrator or administrator de bonis non of a deceased person, whether made under the provisions of any will, foreign or domestic, or any order of court, foreign or domestic, shall be valid and binding, inter alia, upon any heir or devisee and upon any successor in interest of such heir or devisee by whatever manner, in the following cases: First, when such conveyance has with knowledge or means of knowledge of such conveyance, been treated as valid by any such heir or devisee, and the successor in interest thereof, or by such successor in interest, for the period of five (5) years after such conveyance has been ordered or approved by any such court or judge thereof; secondly, when such conveyance has not been sought to be set aside in any court of competent jurisdiction within five (5) years from and after the filing of such conveyance in the office of the county clerk of the county wherein such land is situate.

History.

Laws 1935, ch. 46, § 6; C.S. 1945, § 66-306; W.S. 1957, § 34-86.

§ 34-5-108. Foreign administrator.

Any conveyance of real estate heretofore, ten (10) years or more prior to January 1st, A.D. 1935, recorded in the county where such real estate is situate, executed by any foreign administrator, executor or administrator de bonis non, appointed and acting under an order of any court of any state of competent jurisdiction over estates of decedents in such state, when such order was made by the court wherein such executor, administrator or administrator de bonis non was appointed or the judge thereof, and when such conveyance was made in conformity to the laws of the state in which such administrator or executor was appointed, and any conveyance heretofore, ten (10) years or more prior to January 1st, A.D. 1935, recorded in the county where such real estate is situate, executed by any such executor, administrator or administrator de bonis non, under the provisions of any will duly probated in any court of competent jurisdiction wherever situate, when such conveyance was made in conformity to the law of the state in which such administrator or executor or administrator de bonis non was appointed, shall be as valid and binding upon the heir and devisees of the decedent and their successors in interest, as though such conveyance were made in conformity with the laws of this state; provided, such conveyances herein mentioned were made in accordance with due process of law in such state.

History.

Laws 1935, ch. 46, § 7; C.S. 1945, § 66-307; W.S. 1957, § 34-87.

§ 34-5-109. Copies of proceedings in foreign courts.

Duly certified copies, according to law, of the proceedings in foreign courts, mentioned and referred to in W.S. 34-5-107, 34-5-108 and 34-5-110, when recorded in the office of the county clerk of the county where the land involved is situate, such records, or the certified copies thereof, shall be competent and prima facie evidence of the truth of the contents thereof, and the regularity of the proceedings therein set forth.

History.

Laws 1935, ch. 46, § 12; C.S. 1945, § 66-312; W.S. 1957, § 34-88.

§ 34-5-110. Adverse claims; when adverse claimant barred against purchaser.

Any claimant having acquired any vested right in and to the said real estate conveyed as aforesaid in the two (2) preceding sections [§§ 34-5-107, 34-5-108], adverse to the purchaser under the conveyances executed as aforesaid in the two (2) preceding sections, which said adverse claim was acquired five (5) years prior to January 1, 1935, shall have until the first day of January, 1936, in which to commence an action in a court of competent jurisdiction within this state, to assert and enforce such adverse right, and such vested right shall during the period herein allowed for the commencement of such action, not be affected by the provisions of the two (2) preceding sections, but from and after the time so allowed for the commencement of such action, unless such action has been brought as herein mentioned, all rights of such adverse claimant in and to such real estate shall be forever barred.

History.

Laws 1935, ch. 46, § 8; C.S. 1945, § 66-308; W.S. 1957, § 34-89.

§ 34-5-111. Adverse claims; action by heir against purchaser.

In any action contemplated in the preceding section [§ 34-5-110], commenced and brought by an heir or devisee of such deceased person in this action contemplated, or the successor in interest of such heir or devisee, if it shall appear that such heir or devisee had knowledge, either by personal notice, or constructively under the laws of the state where the estate of such deceased person was administered, of the fact of the sale or the conveyance of such real estate mentioned in the two (2) preceding sections [§§ 34-5-108, 34-5-110], or where such person appeared in the proceedings in court relating thereto, it shall be prima facie evidence against such devisee and heir, and against any successor in interest of such heir or devisee without adequate consideration, that such heir and devisee consented to such sale and conveyance, and intended thereby, and did thereby, vest in the purchaser under such conveyance, or sale, all the right, title and interest which such devisee and heir had in and to such real estate so sold or conveyed at the time of such sale or conveyance, and meant to be estopped thereby to claim any future title or interest therein, and if such action is brought by the successor in interest of such heir or devisee, it shall be presumed in the first instance, that such successor in interest is such without adequate consideration, and provided further, that in all such actions, all such conveyances shall be prima facie of the effect as vesting the complete and clear title of the property conveyed in such conveyance in the grantee therein.

History.

Laws 1935, ch. 46, § 9; C.S. 1945, § 66-309; W.S. 1957, § 34-90.

§ 34-5-112. Effect of preceding sections on pending litigation; enforcement of rights of minor heir in conveyed property.

The provisions of W.S. 34-5-104 through 34-5-108, 34-5-110, 34-5-111, inclusive, shall not affect any pending litigation. And any right which any minor heir may have in and to any property conveyed, transferred or released as in said sections mentioned, may be asserted by bringing an action in any court of competent jurisdiction within one (1) year after such minor heir becomes an adult.

History.

Laws 1935, ch. 46, § 11; C.S. 1945, § 66-311; W.S. 1957, § 34-91; Laws 1973, ch. 213, § 2.

§ 34-5-113. Where release of homestead or marital status of grantor not indicated.

All conveyances by which any estate or interest in real estate is created, alienated, mortgaged or assigned, or by which the title to any real estate may be affected in law or in equity wherein there is no release or waiver of homestead or the marital status of the grantor is not set forth, and which have been or hereafter may be recorded for a period of ten (10) years in the office of the county clerk of the county wherein such real estate is situated, it shall be conclusively presumed that said real estate was not used, occupied or claimed by the grantor, or the spouse of the grantor as a homestead at the time of said conveyance.

History.

Laws 1935, ch. 46, § 13; C.S. 1945, § 66-313; Laws 1949, ch. 31, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 34-92; Laws 2009, ch. 168, § 206.

Cross references. —

As to rights and liabilities of married persons generally, see §§ 20-1-201, 20-1-202.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, deleted “and ex officio register of deeds” following “county clerk.”

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Recovery of damages for breach of contract to convey homestead where only one spouse signed contract, 5 ALR4th 1310.

§ 34-5-114. Gifts to religious and educational uses; generally.

No gift, devise, bequest, transfer, grant or conveyance of real or personal property to religious, educational, charitable or benevolent uses, which shall in other respects be valid under the laws of this state shall be deemed invalid by reason of the indefiniteness or uncertainty of the persons designated as the beneficiaries thereunder in the instrument creating or constituting the same.

History.

Laws 1949, ch. 9, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 34-93.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity, construction, and effect of provisions of charitable trust providing for accumulation of income, 6 ALR4th 903.

Validity, as for a charitable purpose, of trust for publication or distribution of particular books or writings, 34 ALR4th 419.

Lack of consideration as barring enforcement of promise to make charitable contribution or subscription—modern cases, 86 ALR4th 241.

Validity of charitable gift or trust containing gender restrictions on beneficiaries, 90 ALR4th 836.

§ 34-5-115. Gifts to religious and educational uses; existence of prior trust agreements in will.

No such gift, bequest or devise contained in any will executed in accordance with the requirements of law shall be deemed invalid by reason of the incorporation by reference in the will of any written or printed resolution, declaration or trust agreement, identified as existing prior to the execution of such will, and adopted or made by any corporation or corporations authorized by law to accept and execute trusts, creating a trust to assist, encourage and promote the well being or well doing of mankind, or of the inhabitants of any community, provided that a copy of such resolution, declaration or deed of trust, certified by the secretary or assistant secretary, or other officer or officers, of such corporation or corporations under its or their corporate seal or seals, shall have been filed for record in the office of the secretary of state of the state of Wyoming, the secretary of state being hereby authorized and directed to receive and record such resolution, declaration or deed of trust, upon payment of the fees provided by law.

History.

Laws 1949, ch. 9, § 2; W.S. 1957, § 34-94.

Law reviews. —

See “Legal Investment for a Wyoming Trustee,” 12 Wyo. L.J. 130 (1958).

§ 34-5-116. Gifts to religious and educational uses; valid notwithstanding terms are included only by reference.

  1. Any gift, devise or bequest so made to any such corporation in trust for the uses and purposes contained in such resolution, declaration, or deed of trust, shall be valid and effectual, notwithstanding:
    1. That the terms, conditions, uses and purposes of such gift, devise or bequest, are included only by such reference in the will; and, or
    2. That such resolution, declaration, or deed of trust, has been or may be, amended in accordance with the provisions thereof.

History.

Laws 1949, ch. 9, § 3; W.S. 1957, § 34-95.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 34-5-117. Gifts to religious and educational uses; application of W.S. 34-5-114 through 34-5-117.

All the terms and provisions of this act [§§ 34-5-114 through 34-5-117] shall be deemed applicable to all gifts, devises, bequests, transfers, grants or conveyances of real or personal property heretofore made, as well as to those hereafter made, and to all such resolutions, declarations, or deeds of trust as are hereinabove referred to which have been heretofore filed for record as hereinabove provided, as well as those which shall be hereafter so filed for record.

History.

Laws 1949, ch. 9, § 4; W.S. 1957, § 34-96.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity, construction, and effect of provisions of charitable trust providing for accumulation of income, 6 ALR4th 903.

Chapter 6 Rights of Survivors [Renumbered]

  • §§ 34-6-101 through 34-6-103.  [Renumbered.]

§§ 34-6-101 through 34-6-103. [Renumbered.]

Renumbered as §§ 2-9-101 through 2-9-103 by Laws 1979, ch. 142, § 3.
